div.p: THE DUELLIST.
[PRICE ONE SHILLING AND SIX-PENCE.]
THE DUELLIST, A COMEDY.
AS IT IS ACTED AT THE THEATRE ROYAL IN COVENT GARDEN.
WRITTEN BY W. KENRICK, LL. D.
LONDON : PRINTED FOR T. EVANS, NEAR YORK BUILDINGS, IN THE STRAND.

div.head: PREFACE
Extract from the PUBLIC ADVERTISER of Monday, November 22, 1773.

q.p: ON Saturday laſt, a new comedy, called the Duelliſt, was performed, for the firſt time, at Covent-Garden Theatre. Previous to the curtain being drawn up, the following written hand-bill was diſperſed about the houſe.
q.q: Mr. Macklin has been purſued by a malicious party to ſuch a pitch of rancour, that at laſt they have ſucceeded ſo far in their curſed deſigns, as to get him diſcharged this Theatre, and thereby have deprived him of the means of a livelihood : Therefore if the Public have any ſpirit, they will not ſuffer the new play to begin till Mr. Colman promiſes that Mr. Macklin ſhall be engaged again.
q.p:
This hand-bill found its way into the Green-Room, and had a very viſible effect on the performers, as was plainly evident from their confuſion. The piece was received with great marks of approbation, and given out again for Monday, which was attended with ſome hiſſing, but that was greatly overpowered by the general applauſe of the audience. The overture to Thomas and Sally being attended to with ſilence, the greateſt part of the Author's Friends, quitted the Theatre ; which being taken advantage
of by a party in the gallery, a riot enſued ; and the entertainment was not ſuffered to go on till another play was given out for Monday.

div.p: To the above conciſe relation of the circumſtances attending the repreſentation of the following Comedy (as it is given by one of the moſt reſpectable of our diurnal hiſtorians) the Author of the Duelliſt makes no exception or addition. He would be wanting, however, in that reſpect, which he has ever profeſſed and ſhewn for the public opinion, did he not endeavour to obviate ſome objections that have been made to his Piece, and to account, as well as he is able, for the unprecedented ſeverity of its treatment.

As to the author's pretenſions to merit in this ſpecies of writing, it is not for him to boaſt, were there cauſe for boaſting. Becauſe, ſenſible of the neceſſity of a dramatic writer's making the theatre the conſtant ſcene of his obſervation, he can without mortification admit that an author, whoſe ſtudy is the ſtage, bids fairer for ſucceſs on it than another, who, engaged at a diſtance in more ſcientific reſearches, makes its amuſements only his occaſional relaxation from ſeverer and more laborious purſuits. Not that he is without reaſon to be flattered with the applauſe his performance met with in repreſentation ; though, were it otherwiſe, he ſhould not have the vanity to copy after a Corneille, who, in the preface to his Pertharite, which was univerſally condemned, avows boldly, that in ſpite of cenſure his play was a good one and well written. He would have confidence
enough, however, in imitation of as great a writer of our own country, to declare, with Dryden, that the town "had received with applauſe, as bad and as uncorrect plays from other men." As a writer by profeſſion, therefore, whoſe family depends on his induſtry, he conceives it not only prudential in him to convert his amuſements to profit, but that he has a right to expect the theatres ſhould be as open to receive his productions as thoſe of others. It is true, he has not found it ſo, and is ſingularly unlucky in having his pieces performed with impartial applauſe, and then partially baniſhed the ſtage. He is not aſhamed to declare he writes plays not from inclination but from expediency : the object in his view being not dramatic reputation but theatrical emolument ; to which, while he writes no worſe than others (which can hardly be) though it ſhould not be allowed he writes better, he preſumes he is equally entitled.

To account for his diſappointment in the preſent inſtance will not be difficult. Some juſt exceptions may be made to the piece itſelf : the ſcene between the lawyers in the fourth act appeared too long ; in deference however to the opinion of Mr. Colman, who thought its effect would depend greatly on the action, it was riſked, and is here printed at length.

As to the paſſage objected to, on account of its ſuppoſed indelicacy, it is entirely omitted. The author muſt do Mr. Colman, alſo the juſtice to ſay, that he conſtantly excepted againſt it, and had his
more cautious judgement been attended to, it would have been omitted in the repreſentation.

Another exception has been made to the whole of the repreſentation, on account of the confuſion, I might ſay diſtreſs, of ſome of the performers. But if the circumſtances that cauſed it be attended to, ſuch performers were ſo far from being the objects of reprehenſion for playing ill, that it is a wonder they acquitted themſelves ſo well.

To Mr. Macklin the author has nothing, nor ever will have any thing, farther to ſay, than that he imputes the ill ſucceſs of this unfortunate comedy wholly to that performer's reſentment againſt the managers, for having diſcharged him the theatre ; as it was doubtleſs their duty to do at the requiſition of the the majority of an audience. That ill-ſucceſs, indeed has been imputed to cauſes, which to admit, would be to caſt an injurious reflection on perſons, who, the author is well perſuaded, by no means deſerve it.

It has been ſaid that the gentlemen of the law took offence at the liberties taken with their profeſſion and practice, in the characters and dialogue of Witmore and Nonplus. They muſt have too much knowledge and good ſenſe, however, to be ſeriouſly offended at what was deſigned as a mere laugh on the ſtage, or a ſatire on what the beſt of them regret as much as their clients, without having it in their power to remedy it.

A club of bookſellers and a crew of authors are ſaid to have formed a formidable phalanx of oppoſition. The writer doubts not the good intentions of both ; he has endeavoured to ſerve the cauſe of literature too much, to have the good will of thoſe, who are labouring, by every poſſible means, to ruin it. What injury either party might do him in the theatre, the author knows not ; but the ſcribblers have ſhewn ſo little diſcretion in the zeal to abuſe him from the preſs, that he gives them hearty thanks for the ſervice they have undeſignedly done him.

With reſpect to Individuals it has been miſtakenly, or perhaps maliciouſly, propagated that the piece was calculated to ridicule perſons or characters, for whom the author has either the greateſt reſpect, or to whom he is an entire ſtranger. They who read Mr. Fielding's Amelia will ſee from what ſource the author has drawn ſome of the principal characters and incidents. As the reſt of the piece is original, the candid muſt alſo admit that he has made no greater uſe of that writer than dramatic authors have ever been allowed to do with noveliſts, from the practice of Shakeſpear to that of Mr. Colman.

It has been ſuggeſted, that Mr. Garrick had privately planted a party in the houſe to oppoſe the performance. This the author cannot believe ; as, having long ſince declared himſelf that gentleman's open and avowed enemy, he cannot, after
what has publickly paſſed between them, think ſo meanly even of Mr. Garrick as to ſuppoſe he would act otherwiſe than as an enemy equally open and avowed.

It has even been ſaid that the friends of a certain dramatiſt, whoſe name the author forbears to mention, as it is diſguſting to the remembrance of his friends, were powerful in the oppoſition. On this head he will only give a little anecdote, as it was related to him by an auditor, who ſat in the Boxes.

"During the tumult in the theatre about the repetition of the Duelliſt, a Lady who aſked a thing that had the appearance of a gentleman, what was the reaſon of it, was anſwered that "the Man (meaning the author) was obnoxious and therefore his piece muſt be condemned." "Yes, madam," added a gentleman who ſat by, "There are a multitude of animals in this town, to whom the ſpirit of a MAN is as obnoxious as the perſon of a WOMAN."—May the author of the Duelliſt be ever obnoxious to ſuch Critics.

Laſtly, it has been urged, that the Author had not friends enough in the houſe to ſupport the piece. If by this is meant that the piece had not merit enough to make itſelf friends, it is falſe, as appears from the above-cited relation. While its friends remained in the houſe, it was applauded by a great majority ; but, when a conſiderable number of theſe went away, and their places were ſupplied by riotous partizans,
who could not before get into the houſe and had not ſeen it, it is no wonder that both the piece and the author ſhould fatally feel the want of friends.

If this want, on the other hand, be imputed to the Author's neglect of introducing people into the theatre, to influence the judgment of the impartial part of the audience in his favour, he takes a pride in having ever paid in this reſpect a proper deference to the Public ; whom he ſhould think he inſulted, had he acted otherwiſe, and made perſonal intereſt to ſupport his pretenſions to literary merit.

q.l: Too proud to beg, too modeſt to demand,
By merit only would he fall or ſtand ;
He only aſks a fair and candid hearing.

div.p: This indeed is cruelly denied him, by the interruption of his play ; but he hopes will not be ſo on a future occaſion ; the Author having another piece accepted at the ſame theatre ; the parts of which being already written out, and the whole ready for rehearſal, he doubts not the Manager will give him an early opportunity of repairing the loſs, attending his preſent diſappointment : Indeed he ſtill places ſo much confidence on the juſtice and generoſity of the Public, as to ſlatter himſelf he ſhall not ultimately ſuffer by truſting, without party or cabal, to the candour and impartiality of his Auditors.

div.head: PROLOGUE.
div.p: And ſpoken by Mr. SMITH.

sp.l: DEAF to the bar, the pulpit, and the throne.
And aw'd, if aw'd, by ridicule alone,
The Daring Duelliſt, in captious pride,
Hath long his friend, his king, his God defied.
Thrice happy we, if laughter from the ſtage
Should cure this frantic folly in the age :
Happy the father, ſiſter, mother, wife,
Who prize a ſon's, a brother's, huſband's life,
Should we dethrone the tyrant, whoſe caprice
So oft endangers and deſtroys their peace ;
Whoſe fell deſpotic ſway doth ev'n enſlave
The great, the good, the generous and the brave ;
Nay, arrant cowards, forc'd into a fray,
Now fight, becauſe they fear—to run away,
Our modiſh heroes, it is true, may bluſter,
Take heart of grace, and all their ſpirits muſter,
This peaceful reformation to oppoſe,
And take, in talk, our author by the noſe.—
But, when the comic muſe true humour fires,
And zeal the poignant fatiriſt inſpires
Againſt abſurdity to ſet his wit,
And folly's mark, altho' in mirth, to hit,
There lies more peril in his pointed words,
Than lies, alack, in twenty of their ſwords!
Encouraged hence, the poet of to night,
Againſt theſe angry boys hath dar'd to write ;
For, by the way, it is on you he reckons,
Nature's own cauſe eſpouſing, as his ſeconds.
On this preſumption doth he take the field,
Hoping to make the ſtouteſt bluſterer yield ;
If ſilent they, who neither love nor fear him,
Conſent to ſit, and patiently will hear him,
If they do this, he doubts not to diſperſe
Their preſent prejudice for carte and tierce;
Their pointleſs ſwords to parry with his pen,
And piſtol-proof, put down theſe mighty men!

SCENE, LONDON.

div.head: SCENE I. Witmore's Chambers in the Temple.
div.stage: Mr. WITMORE and Capt. BOOTHBY.

sp.speaker: WIT.
sp.p: Really, George, your ſituation is ſo critical that I am not lawyer enough to adviſe you. Sir Solomon, your father-in-law, ſtill ſo inflexible, ſay you?

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: As poſitiveneſs and parſimony can make him. It is not above two years ſince I married ; and, notwithſtanding every proper ſubmiſſion on my part, the earneſt and repeated ſolicitations of his daughter, and the warmeſt interceſſions of our friends, he ſtill ſeems inexorable as ever.

sp.speaker: WIT.
sp.p: That's ſtrange! Time generally ſoftens reſentments of this kind. But the love of money, and an habitual paſſion for artificial trifles, extinguiſh the ſparks of natural affection. As I have acquired, however ſome credit with him, I will try, when he comes to town, how far my influence extends. And yet, Boothby, this may be carrying my friendſhip for you too far.

sp.speaker: BOOTH,
sp.p: Why ſo?

sp.speaker: WIT.
sp.p: You know he has a niece, who came over ſome time ſince from India to finiſh her education.

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: I am told he has adopted her for his daughter ; and in her favour, it is ſuppoſed, will diſinherit my wife.

sp.speaker: WIT.
sp.p: In which caſe, if I ſhould become her huſband—

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: You!

sp.speaker: WIT.
sp.p: I! Why not, if the lady will have me?

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: And have you any ſerious thoughts of Emilia?

sp.speaker: WIT.
sp.p: Why, really I do think ſeriouſly of her ſometimes. The month, I ſpent, during the laſt vacation at Sir Solomon's country ſeat, gave me an opportunity of ſeeing a number of good qualities in her. She is young, it is true ; but that's a fault one may eaſily put up with in a woman.

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: Nay, I know little of her.—Sir Solomon and his lady have ſtrictly prohibited her having any intercourſe with Mrs. Boothby.

sp.speaker: WIT.
sp.p: To reconcile you, therefore, to them now, will be at leaſt a diſintereſted proof of my regard for you, George.

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: It will ſo, and yet no greater than I expect from it. Your generoſity of diſpoſition, Witmore—

sp.speaker: WIT.
sp.p: Nay, no compliments between friends.—On what terms are you with your own relation? With Lord Lovemore, and his brother-in-law, General Gantlet?

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: On the beſt, if I may depend on their profeſſions. His Lordſhip is now exerting his intereſt to procure me a regiment ; and, as he tells me, with confidence of ſucceſs.

sp.speaker: WIT.
sp.p: I am glad of it—Your promotion may have a good effect on Sir Solomon.

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: In the mean time, however, the pay of a Captain of foot, Witmore, is ſo diſproportioned to the way of living in this gay town—

sp.speaker: WIT.
sp.p: That you cannot indulge in the pleaſures of it.

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: Nay, hardly ſubſiſt very creditably, and pay the court that is neceſſary to preferment.

sp.speaker: WIT.
sp.p: What think you of my laying open your circumſtances to the General? He is my client, and I know you are down for ſomething handſome in his will.

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: Yes, but I am afraid he'll not be prevailed on to part with any thing while he lives.

sp.speaker: WIT.
sp.p: Well, you muſt comfort yourſelf then by reflecting that cannot be long. He is ſo fond of duelling, that ſome antagoniſt or other will ſoon kill him, or he will come to be hanged for killing his antagoniſt. He narrowly eſcaped the laſt time he killed his man, as he calls it, and yet he's as captious and quarrelſome as ever.

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: He is, indeed, unaccountably exceptious. But, here he comes.

div.stage: Enter General GANTLET.

sp.speaker: GAN.
sp.p: Well, Barriſter, how is it? —What, George Boothby! By the lord, my boy, I am heartily glad to ſee thee.

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: I thank you, General. I hope I have the pleaſure of ſeeing you well to-day?

sp.speaker: GAN.
sp.p: Never better, my dear boy. —I have juſt had the ſuperlative ſatisfaction of chaſtiſing a ſcoundrel.

sp.speaker: WIT.
sp.p: What tilting again, General?

sp.speaker: GAN.
sp.p: A cool thruſt only—But 'twas in him—I paid the raſcal home. Here—here—Boothby—here I had him— through—fairly through, by the dignity of man!

sp.speaker: WIT.
sp.p: Not his body, I hope.

sp.speaker: GAN.
sp.p: His midriſſ! that's all!

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: You alarm me, General—who—where?

sp.speaker: GAN.
sp.p: Nay don't concern thyſelf, my dear boy—The rogue was in luck—a ſimple perſoration, the ſurgeon called it ; he tells me there is no danger.

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: I am glad to hear that.

sp.speaker: WIT.
sp.p: And pray, General, what was the cauſe of quarrel? How did your antagoniſt offend you?

sp.speaker: GAN.
sp.p: Me! Barriſter! He did not offend me. —Give me thy hand, Boothby, I have done thee an injury ; which nothing but the height of friendſhip in me can excuſe, and the moſt exalted ſublimity of it in thee forgive.

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: What is all this? How can you have ſo highly injured me, General? Be how it will, I promiſe you I forgive you with all my heart.

sp.speaker: GAN.
sp.p: I knew thou waſt a good-natured lad and would overlook it, or, by the Lord, thou ſhouldſt have taken him our thyſelf.

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: How, General! Have you been taking up a quarrel of mine :—It was obliging in you ; —but I could wiſh—

sp.speaker: GAN.
sp.p: Oh! Sir! it's enough, I underſtand you, —you are perfectly in the right, I ſhould have been more punctilious. —It was impertinent in me, to be ſure. —A friend may be ſometimes too officious. —However, Sir, if you are diſſatisfied, I am at your ſervice. —Call me out—You can fight—I draw my ſword for no man who dares not draw his own.

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: Nay, but underſtand me, General. If you have taken up any cauſe of mine, I am ſo far from reſenting it as an injury, that I think myſelf obliged to you. You know I am as tenacious of the punctilio as yourſelf ; and would never be ſo rude as to take up the cauſe of a ſtranger : but among friends it is quite another thing.

sp.speaker: GAN.
sp.p: Right, boy. When I commanded in Ireland, my doublet was pinked like the flounces of a fine lady's ſilk petticoat ; and all in the cauſe of my friends. The man who would not be run through the body for his friend, ought to be kicked out of the world for a ſcoundrel.

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: An heroic ſentiment, General. —But who was your antagoniſt? I hope, for your ſake, he's really out of danger.

sp.speaker: GAN.
sp.p:
Nay, the raſcal himſelf, I believe, is hardly worth the care of the ſurgeon. I ſhould have wiped my contaminated
ſword and left him to his fate, but that it would have been too great an honour for him to die by the hands of a gentlemen.

sp.speaker: WIT.
sp.p: And yet, General, I am afraid your magnanimity will one day or other betray you into the doing ſome raſcal or other that honour.

sp.speaker: GAN.
sp.p: Well Sir, and what then? Would you inſinuate that a gentleman has not a right to do himſelf juſtice by putting to death a ſcoundrel?

sp.speaker: WIT.
sp.p: By the laws, General?

sp.speaker: GAN.
sp.p: By the laws of honour, Sir.

sp.speaker: WIT.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, and by the laws of the land too, if he have a mind to be hanged for it, A man may break all the laws in the ſtatute book, if he be diſpoſed to pay the penalties.

sp.speaker: GAN.
sp.p: How, Sir? ſhall not I annihilate a raſcal? Do the laws of England afford protection to ſcoundrels?

sp.speaker: WIT.
sp.p: To a great number, noble General : and ſo do the laws of honour too ; by which the ſcoundrel has as often the advantage of the man of honour as the man of honour of the ſcoundrel. Let us ſuppoſe, General, that your antagoniſt's ſkill or agility had been greater than yours; would that have conferred probity on him or reflected infamy on you?

sp.speaker: GAN.
sp.p: Infamy on me, Sir!

sp.speaker: WIT.
sp.p: Excuſe me, General, I ſpeak only by way of hypotheſis.

sp.speaker: GAN.
sp.p: Hypotheſis! Sir! Rot your hypotheſis, Sir. [takes Boothby aſide.] Boothby, have you ſeen the peer to-day.

sp.speaker: BOOTH,
sp.p: Lord Lovemore? No, Sir.

sp.speaker: GAN.
sp.p: Then you don't know how his affair has ended.

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: What affair, General?

sp.speaker: GAN.
sp.p: With the fellow, that affronted him laſt night.

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: I heard nothing of it.

sp.speaker: GAN.
sp.p: Come, come along with me, then. I muſt know how it ended [turning about to Witmore.] Hypotheſis! Ha! Mr. Barriſter!

sp.speaker: WIT.
sp.p: No offence, I hope, General! I think I could put a caſe in point—

sp.speaker: GAN.
sp.p: A caſe in point! With the point of honour, Sir? Offence, Sir! Yes Sir, there is offence, Sir. —Come, come along, Boothby. Theſe lawyers of the Inns of Court know nothing of the laws of honour! —Hypotheſis, Ha! Mr. Barriſter! Come along, Boothby, Hypotheſis! Quotha! [Exeunt GAN. and BOOTH.

sp.speaker: WITMORE ſolus.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha! What a captious mortal! Could he find nobody elſe to quarrel with, he would certainly take exceptions at himſelf and tilt with his own ſhadow! Enter a SERVANT.

sp.speaker: SERV.
sp.p: A card from Sir Solomon Bauble, Sir.

sp.speaker: WIT.
sp.p: I did not know he was in London. [reads the card.] Sir Solomon Bauble's compliments to Mr. Witmore—would be glad to conſult him on a family affair, that concerns him nearly. —If this ſhould be Boothby's buſineſs now! I wiſh it may. —Is the meſſenger gone?

sp.speaker: SERV.
sp.p: No, Sir, he is without.

sp.speaker: WIT.
sp.p: Let me ſee him. [Exeunt.

div.head: SCENE II. An Apartment at Lord Lovemore's.
div.stage: Enter Lord and Lady LOVEMORE.

sp.speaker: Lady LOVE.
sp.p:
Inſupportable! is it not enough, my Lord, that I have given ſcope to your licentiouſneſs, by winking at your gallantries, that you would make me openly countenance
them? Do you think me really ſo blind as not to ſee your deſigns on Mrs. Boothby?

sp.speaker: Lord LOVE.
sp.p: Look you, Madam, while I contribute to your pleaſures I expect you will not controul mine.

sp.speaker: Lady LOVE.
sp.p: My pleaſures, as you call them, my Lord, are unexceptionable. I have no amuſements but what are common to women of quality.

sp.speaker: Lord LOVE.
sp.p: Nor I any but what are common to men of quality. In a word, Lady Lovemore, we have been too long married to impoſe any longer on the world, and we ought to know the world too well to impoſe any longer on ourſelves.

sp.speaker: Lady LOVE.
sp.p: In what? my Lord!

sp.speaker: Lord LOVE.
sp.p: In keeping up the appearance of domeſtic harmony, which no longer ſubſiſts.

sp.speaker: Lady LOVE.
sp.p: Appearances govern the world, my Lord ; and it is they impoſe on themſelves, who will not enjoy the ſhadow becauſe they have loſt the ſubſtance.

sp.speaker: Lord LOVE.
sp.p: Then you think we once poſſeſſed it.

sp.speaker: Lady LOVE.
sp.p: I thought we married for love, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Lord LOVE.
sp.p: I thought ſo too : but I believe we were both miſtaken.

sp.speaker: Lady LOVE.
sp.p: Why ſo?

sp.speaker: Lord LOVE.
sp.p: Becauſe there has been ſo little loſt between us, and yet there ſeems to be none left.

sp.speaker: Lady LOVE.
sp.p: The want of love, my Lord, ſhould not baniſh decency.

sp.speaker: Lord LOVE.
sp.p: But it ſhould baniſh jealouſy, Madam.

sp.speaker: Lady LOVE.
sp.p: Then your Lordſhip thinks me jealous, and yet you imagine there is as little love left on my ſide as yours.

sp.speaker: Lord LOVE.
sp.p: The leſs the better, as there is no ſatisfying the ſurmizes of a ſuſpicious woman.

sp.speaker: Lady LOVE.
sp.p: Indeed, my Lord, you are miſtaken. You do it effectually by converting ſuſpicion into certainty. I have learned to ſupport the being an object of private neglect, but I am not quite ſo meek as to ſit down expoſed to public contempt.

sp.speaker: Lord LOVE.
sp.p: You may avoid it, madam, by retiring from public notice. Our houſe in Glouceſterſhire is ready to receive you ; and, if you except to the company, I keep, in town, you may keep what company you pleaſe in the country. The poſt-coach ſhall be ready tomorrow morning, unleſs Mrs. Boothby makes one of our party to-night.

sp.speaker: Lady LOVE.
sp.p: My Lord, my Lord, I will ſee my brother Gantlet before I determine to ſtay or go.

sp.speaker: Lord LOVE.
sp.p: Your brother Gantlet, madam! Do you mean to intimidate me with your family bully? Let that bluſterer interfere, and I will immure you in the country for life.

sp.speaker: Lady LOVE.
sp.p: The country! And at this time of year! What cruelty? Is it poſſible your Lordſhip can be in earneſt?

sp.speaker: Lord LOVE.
sp.p: Your Ladyſhip may put me to the trial, if you diſlike the alternative. I leave you a moment to deliberate on the choice. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Lady LOVEMORE alone.
sp.p:
Barbarous tyrant! He knows, I doat upon living in town, and deteſt the gloomy ſolitude of his Glouceſterſhire dungeon. I will ſometime or other be revenged on him for this treatment. My brother's temper indeed is ſo violent, that, unleſs things are carried to extremity, his remedy may be worſe than the diſeaſe. But I will diſſemble with this inſolent intriguer of mine ; and, if I have art enough, defeat the execution of his deſigns by counteracting him. —I ſhall be able to do this the more effectually by ſtaying in town. —Mrs. Boothby is at preſent, I believe, a woman of honour, and loves her huſband ; whom Lord Lovemore is flattering with favours and feeding with promiſes, in order to effect the ſeduction of his wife! What traitors
are men! And mine the moſt inſulting of traitors! With what an air of aſſurance did he in fact confeſs it. Look you, Madam, while I contribute to your pleaſures, I expect you will not controul mine. But, if Boothby and his wife are not two errant idiots, I will controul your pleaſures, my fine ſcheming Lord, even while you think I am contributing to them. —Here, Echo! Bring me pens, ink, and paper.

div.stage: Enter ECHO.

sp.speaker: ECH.
sp.p: Pens, ink and paper, my Lady?

sp.speaker: Lady LOVE.
sp.p: It is plain you heard, Mrs. Pert.

sp.speaker: ECH.
sp.p: Heard Mrs. Pert! my Lady!

sp.speaker: Lady LOVE.
sp.p: Wilt thou never leave off that odious trick of repeating one's words?

sp.speaker: ECH.
sp.p: Repeating your words, my Lady?

sp.speaker: Lady LOVE.
sp.p: Canſt thou ſay nothing, wench, but what I ſay?

sp.speaker: ECH.
sp.p: Nothing but what you ſay, my Lady?

sp.speaker: Lady LOVE.
sp.p: Out of my ſight, thou incorrigible wretch.

sp.speaker: ECH.
sp.p: Wretch, my Lady!

sp.speaker: Lady LOVE.
sp.p: Begone, I ſay-

sp.speaker: ECH.
sp.p: Gone, my Lady. [Exit ECHO.

div.stage: Re-enter Lord LOVEMORE.

sp.speaker: Lord LOVE.
sp.p: Well, Madam, have you reflected on my propoſal? Do you chuſe to reſide in town or in the country? in London or Glouceſterſhire?

sp.speaker: Lady LOVE.
sp.p: You know, my Lord, I hate Glouceſterſhire.

sp.speaker: Lord LOVE.
sp.p: Well, madam, to indulge your inclination for company ; what ſay you to Somerſetſhire? To Bath?

sp.speaker: Lady LOVE.
sp.p: Out of the ſeaſon, my Lord! I would as willingly go out of the world.

sp.speaker: Lord LOVE.
sp.p: Well, madam, you know the conditions of our reſidence under the ſame roof, in town.

sp.speaker: Lady LOVE.
sp.p: Why, look you, my Lord, as I know you may plead precedent among a number of our acquaintance, if I thought you would pay any tolerable regard to appearances, I might compound with you. It may be prudent for a neglected wife to ſeem eaſy under the indifference of her huſband ; but ſhe muſt be meek and mean-ſpirited indeed, if ſhe can ſubmit to be inſulted by his miſtreſs. Not that I think you will ſucceed with Mrs. Boothby. She is, I believe, ſo fond of her huſband, that, I am perſuaded, I may ſafely truſt her with you.

sp.speaker: Lord LOVE.
sp.p: Do ſo then, and be ſatisfied if I keep up appearances, as you term it. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Lady LOVE,
sp.p: I will, my Lord, and hope to fit you too at the keeping up of appearances. [Exit.

div.head: SCENE III. An Apartment at Sir Solomon Bauble's.

sp.stage: Enter Sir SOLOMON and Lady BAUBLE.

sp.speaker: Lady BAU.
sp.p: Pooh, Sir Solomon, what a rout is here about an old ruſty counter and a roll of cinder-coloured parchment? I ſuppoſe Mrs. Bruſh has flirted them away in duſting the dining-room. —Mrs. Bruſh! —

sp.speaker: Sir SOL.
sp.p:
No, no. My lady! I tell you I have been robbed, plundered! I have loſt two curioſities that would have cauſed the muſeum at Bauble-hall to be admired by all the antiquaries and connoiſſeurs in Europe. An Otho, in the higheſt preſervation, and a Greek manuſcript dug out of the ruins of Herculaneum!
Enter Mrs. BRUSH.
Who has been here, huſſey, in my abſence this morning?

sp.speaker: BRUSH.
sp.p: Nobody, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir SOL.
sp.p: Nobody, Sir! But, I ſay, ſomebody has been here—ſomebody muſt have been here. Where's my antique? my Otho?

sp.speaker: BRUSH.
sp.p: Indeed, Sir, here has been nobody but Dr. Birdlime and another of the letterati from the Antic-queerian Society.

sp.speaker: Sir SOL.
sp.p: And you ſhew'd theſe nobodies into the dining-room, did you?

sp.speaker: BRUSH.
sp.p: As I knew your worſhip knew one of the gentlemen, Sir, and I thoft the other gentlemen was another gentleman ; and eſpecially as they were both Antic-queerians, I thoft them next kin to nobody. Indeed I thoft no harm, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir SOL.
sp.p: You thoft! you thoughtleſs baggage! who taught you to think? Get you gone about your buſineſs!

sp.speaker: BRUSH.
sp.p: (aſide) Here's a fuſs indeed about their Othurs and anticks. [Exit BRUSH.

sp.speaker: Sir SOL.
sp.p: Dr. Birdlime eh! Yes, yes, I knew if ever he came in the way, my medals would ſtick to his fingers. But if I do not proſecute the pilſering quack with the utmoſt ſeverity of the law. —Egad, I'll go to Sir John Fielding and take out a warrant to ſearch his houſe immediately.

sp.speaker: Lady BAU.
sp.p:
Fiddle faddle, Sir Solomon, the copper-ſmith, who made that Otho, can make another ; and, as for the loſs of your manuſcript, I'll preſent your muſeum with my ſentimental journey to Margate ; which Dr. Pompous ſays is worth all the manuſcripts of Herculaneum put together. —But come, Sir Solomon, we have matters to mind of more importance. — I have communicated to your niece Emmeline, the arrival of
her intended huſband, Governor Mammon, from India, and bade her prepare to receive him accordingly.

sp.speaker: Sir SOL.
sp.p: Well, and ſhe was overjoyed at the news! Eh!

sp.speaker: Lady BAU.
sp.p: Quite the reverſe.

sp.speaker: Sir SOL.
sp.p: How!

sp.speaker: Lady BAU.
sp.p: The family ſeems doomed, Sir Solomon, to have all its projects fruſtrated by the perverſeneſs of undutiful children. Your daughter threw herſelf away on that Captain Boothby, a young fellow not worth a groat, and here is your niece averſe truly to marry governor Mammon, a man as rich as a nabob.

sp.speaker: Sir SOL.
sp.p: And yet you would have forgiven your daughter, as you will your niece, I ſuppoſe.

sp.speaker: Lady BAU.
sp.p: I forgive them, Sir Solomon! I would have you to know that I have a ſpirit as implacable and unforgiving as yourſelf.

sp.speaker: Sir SOL.
sp.p: Poh! Poh! You, fooliſh women, are eaſily prevailed on to do any thing. But why my daughter, and my niece? Madam! Why not your daughter and your niece? No ſuch perverſeneſs runs in the blood of the Baubles. They would marry any toy for money.

sp.speaker: Lady BAU.
sp.p: I thank you, huſband, but, vain as you are, I did not marry you for love. The family of the Trinkets, whence I am deſcended, never ſacrificed their intereſt to their paſſions, or indulged indeed any paſſion but that of intereſt.

sp.speaker: Sir SOL.
sp.p: It is much, wiſe, that children ſhould not take after their parents.

sp.speaker: Lady BAU.
sp.p: You a philoſopher, huſband, and not know that the commixture of two limpid fluids will ſometimes generate opacity. Would you have me account for the irregularities of a luſus naturae, or unravel the tortuoſities of a froward imagination.

sp.speaker: Sir SOL.
sp.p: No, No. That is a taſk a little beyond the capacity of a woman.

sp.speaker: Lady BAU.
sp.p: The capacity of a woman, Sir! And do you ſtill maintain the prepoſterous abſurdity of ſuperior intellect in man? Does not hiſtory afford innumerable inſtances of equal endowments in women? What were Semiramis, Artemiſia, Thomyris, Zenobia, and the no leſs eminent Arataphila, among the ancients?

sp.speaker: Sir SOL.
sp.p: Zounds! What a ſtring have I touched upon? Now will ſhe run over the catalogue of all the cunning gypſies and female fortune-tellers that have plagued the world, from the witch of Endor down to mother Shipton.

sp.speaker: Lady BAU.
sp.p: What were Catherine de Medicis, Lucretia, Cornaro, Anna Maria Schurman, and Madam Dacier, among the moderns?

sp.speaker: Sir SOL.
sp.p: All female furies, or petticoated pedants, I dare anſwer for them.

sp.speaker: Lady BAU.
sp.p:
Nay, among our contemporaries, is not my Lady Betty Comment a ſecond Ariſtotle? Mrs. Politic another Tacitus? And does not Madam Sweet-wort, the brewer's wife at Redriff, write odes with the pen of a Pindar? —Does not— Enter a SERVANT.
How dare you, Sir, come in without knocking at the door?

div.stage: [turning in a pet, walks towards the back part of the ſtage.]

sp.speaker: Sir SOL.
sp.p: A reprieve! —A reprieve! —Come, come in, Thomas, my lady is only a little in her female altitudes this morning. What's the matter?

sp.speaker: SERV.
sp.p: A letter from Governor Mammon, Sir, —His chairmen have ſet down two cheſts in the hall ; a preſent, they ſay, to your worſhip and my Lady.

sp.speaker: Sir SOL.
sp.p: A preſent! Eh! Are the Cheſts heavy, Thomas?

sp.speaker: SERV.
sp.p: Very heavy, an't pleaſe your worſhip.

sp.speaker: Sir SOL.
sp.p: The more heavy, the more likely to be welcome, Thomas. A cheſt of guineas might be too light! Give the fellows ſomething to drink, and I'll come to you preſently. [Exit SERVANT.

sp.speaker: Lady BAU.
sp.p: [returning to the front of the ſtage.] The capacity of women truly!

sp.speaker: Sir SOL.
sp.p: Prithee, my Lady, don't let ſuch a trifle diſturb you. Governor Mammon is arrived in town, and has ſent you a preſent this morning to put you in a good humour. And I doubt not, when I come to talk to my niece, ſhe will receive him as ſhe ought to do. The Governor, I ſee, knows how to recommend himſelf.

sp.speaker: Lady BAU.
sp.p: To be ſure the ſuperiority of your maſculine underſtanding, Sir Solomon, muſt prevail on my niece to do any thing. As to the Governor, indeed, it muſt be owned his oriental manner of making approaches by preſents, is a captivating mode of addreſs. But let us ſee what he has ſent us : the letter, I ſuppoſe, will inform you.

sp.speaker: Sir SOL.
sp.p: Ay, let us ſee, let us ſee. [Putting on his ſpectacles.] [He reads.] Governor Mammon preſents his compliments to Sir Solomon Bauble and Lady : will take the earlieſt opportunity of paying them his perſonal reſpects, and of claiming his right in their amiable niece. In the mean time, begs Lady Bauble's acceptance of— Very polite and well-worded indeed. [pulls off his ſpectacles.]

sp.speaker: Lady BAU.
sp.p: Acceptance of what, Sir Solomon?

sp.speaker: Sir SOL.
sp.p:
Ay, let us ſee, let us ſee. [Putting on his ſpectacles.]
[Reads again.] Begs Lady Bauble's acceptance of a cheſt of ornamental china.

sp.speaker: Lady BAU.
sp.p: Magnificent, no doubt, and worth my acceptance!

sp.speaker: Sir SOL.
sp.p: Piſh! a parcel of pot-bellied pagods and niddlenoddle mandarins; toys for fooliſh women, and play-things for children.

sp.speaker: Lady BAU.
sp.p: Fooliſh women, again, Sir Solomon! I would have you to know—

sp.speaker: Sir SOL.
sp.p: I do. I do. You have told me of it a thouſand times already.

sp.speaker: Lady BAU.
sp.p: What have I told you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir SOL.
sp.p: That fooliſh women are prodigiouſly wiſe, madam. But pray let us ſee what the Governor has ſent me. [Reads again.] And Sir Solomon's of two curioſities, he hopes not unworthy a place in the muſeum of ſo celebrated a virtuoſo : the one a manuſcript ſermon of an Eaſtern Bramin on the duty of women—to bury themſelves with their deceaſed huſbands.

sp.speaker: Lady BAU.
sp.p: Horrid! Why the importation of oriental manuſcripts ſhould be prohibited with popiſh maſs-books.

sp.speaker: Sir SOL.
sp.p: Yes, wife, if they were likely to make as many converts. But the Bramins will make no proſelytes here. Our wanton widows would rather run the riſk of killing a ſecond huſband than bury themſelves with the firſt.

sp.speaker: Lady BAU.
sp.p: What fooliſh women, Sir Solomon, not to be guided by your wiſe men of the Eaſt!

sp.speaker: Sir SOL.
sp.p:
Ha! What's this? [reads] The other! —Sure my ſpectacles deceive me! [pulling off his ſpectacles and wiping them ; then holding up the letter to the light.] No. It is—It is—
The mummy of an Egyptian Princeſs! Ineſtimable! Invaluable! A preſent for a King! Have my niece! He deſerves the niece of an Emperor! The mummy of an Egyptian Princeſs! I ſhall be the envy of all the virtuoſi, the connoſcenti, the dilettanti in Europe.

sp.speaker: Lady BAU.
sp.p: The old fool! In raptures with an odious mummy! How wonderful the ſuperiority of maſculine wiſdom! [Exit.

sp.speaker: Sir SOL.
sp.p: Nay, don't be jealous, my lady, but I can't contain my tranſports. I muſt fly to the preſence of her highneſs, my Egyptian Princeſs. [Exit.

div.head: SCENE I. Capt. Boothby's Lodgings at Mrs. Goodwill's.
div.stage: Mrs. BOOTHBY and Mrs. GOODWILL.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BOOTH.
sp.p: You ſurprize me, Mrs. Goodwill! General Gantlet fight a duel about me! For what?

sp.speaker: Mrs. GOOD.
sp.p: Oh, madam! General Gantlet, they ſay, will fight a duel about any body and for any thing.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BOOTH.
sp.p: Yes! but ſurely not about any body for nothing! What could be ſaid of me to provoke him?

sp.speaker: Mrs. GOOD.
sp.p: Some young ſpark, it ſeems, at the tiltyard, obſerved that Lord Lovemore was fond of promoting officers that had pretty wives.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BOOTH.
sp.p: And how did that regard me?

sp.speaker: Mrs. GOOD.
sp.p: Nay, madam, you need not beg a compliment ; but the ſarcaſm was plainly levelled at the lady of Captain Boothby.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BOOTH.
sp.p: How impudent is calumny! Deteſtable ſtanderers! Lord Lovemore, Mrs. Goodwill, is one of the moſt generous of men.

sp.speaker: Mrs. GOOD.
sp.p: They ſay, indeed, madam, that he is very generous where he takes.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BOOTH.
sp.p: Where he takes! What do you mean, Mrs. Goodwill? Do you imagine then his Lordſhip has any deſigns on me?

sp.speaker: Mrs. GOOD.
sp.p: Have you no reaſon to imagine it, then, madam?

sp.speaker: Mrs. BOOTH.
sp.p: None in the world! His behaviour to me has been always the moſt diſtant and reſpectful.

sp.speaker: Mrs. GOOD.
sp.p: It may not be the leſs deſigning for that, madam.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BOOTH.
sp.p: Indeed I have hardly ever ſeen him but in company with his Lady.

sp.speaker: Mrs. GOOD.
sp.p: And that you think the ſafeſt, madam?

sp.speaker: Mrs. BOOTH.
sp.p: Doubtleſs!

sp.speaker: Mrs. GOOD.
sp.p: There are very condeſcending wives, among women of rank in this licentious age, madam.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BOOTH.
sp.p: Fie, fie, Mrs. Goodwill, there can be women of no rank ſo condeſcending as you would inſinuate. — You are too cenſorious; by much too cenſorious, Mrs. Goodwill. I beg you will throw out no ſuch injurious intimations againſt any one in my hearing again.

sp.speaker: Mrs. GOOD.
sp.p: I am ſorry my freedom of ſpeech ſhould offend, madam. [Aſide as ſhe goes out] Poor young lady! She knows little of the ways of theſe wicked times!

sp.speaker: Mrs. BOOTH.
sp.p: Bleſs me! What ſtrange notions enter into the heads of ſome people!

div.stage: Enter Lady LOVEMORE.

sp.speaker: Lady LOVE.
sp.p: My dear Mrs. Boothby, how do you to day? I was determined to be my own meſſenger this morning, that no accident might deprive me of your company. You muſt be of our party to night. A little, private, ſelect party, quite among ourſelves. I came on purpoſe to take no denial.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BOOTH.
sp.p: Your Ladyſhip is ſo obliging ; but indeed I' had a pre-engagement.

sp.speaker: Lady LOVE.
sp.p: I will hear of no pre-engagements. You muſt come and play a pool at quadrille with the ladies; while my Lord and the Captain are engaged with the gentlemen at whiſt.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BOOTH.
sp.p: Mr. Boothby, madam, hath ſolemnly renounced the game.

sp.speaker: Lady LOVE.
sp.p: Raſh vows, Mrs. Boothby, you know, are made to be broke. My Lord will overcome his ſcruples on that ſcore, I warrant you, ſo that you can have no excuſe.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BOOTH.
sp.p: In that caſe, my Lady, I will certainly do myſelf the pleaſure to wait on you.

sp.speaker: Lady LOVE.
sp.p: Nay, you poſitively muſt come ; we cannot do without you. You will pardon me, my dear, but I muſt excuſe myſelf at twenty other places—Nay—you ſhan't ſtir— My chair is in the hall. —Adieu, my dear Mrs. Boothby. [Exit ceremoniouſly. Mrs. BOOTHBY alone. How perfectly well-bred and obliging! How can Mrs. Goodwill think ill of ſuch a woman? Really, theſe good people who let lodgings are too apt to ſpeak ill of their betters. —And yet, ſomehow, I don't like the tale ſhe told me about General Gantlet. She has ſeen much of the world, and appears to be a diſcerning kind of woman. I know not whether I ſhould altogether ſlight her hints. They were given too with ſuch an air of ſignificance. There may be more in this buſineſs than ſhe has told me ; for why ſhould ſo ſilly a ſpeech give ſuch offence to the General?

div.stage: Re-enter Mrs. GOODWILL.

sp.speaker: Mrs. GOOD.
sp.p: Bleſs me, madam! I hope you did not ſay a word, of what I hinted, to Lady Lovemore : the ſhortneſs of her viſit alarmed me.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BOOTH.
sp.p: That would have been indiſcreet, indeed, Mrs. Goodwill ; as I am convinced, however you may be miſtaken in her Ladyſhip, you meant no ill to me. But pray was that idle ſaying all that paſſed, to provoke the General ſo highly?

sp.speaker: Mrs. GOOD.
sp.p: Nothing more that I heard ; except that the gentleman added, his Lordſhip choſe to procure preferment for his friends abroad, that he might occaſionally pay a charitable viſit to their wives at home!

sp.speaker: Mrs. BOOTH.
sp.p: Then it is plain the reflection could not reſpect me. Captain Boothby is to have a regiment in England ; and he hath ſolemnly promiſed I ſhall go with him, if he be ordered abroad.

sp.speaker: Mrs. GOOD.
sp.p: Yes, madam, but the promiſes of a huſband ſometimes bind as little as thoſe of a lover.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BOOTH.
sp.p: Nay, Mrs. Goodwill, I muſt hear nothing againſt my huſband.

sp.speaker: Mrs. GOOD.
sp.p: I beg pardon, madam—I have done. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BOOTH.
sp.p: I will exact, however, another promiſe from Mr. Boothby, that go where he will I ſhall accompany him. [Exit.

div.head: SCENE II. An Antichamber in the Houſe of Governor Mammon.
div.stage: Enter Sir SOLOMON BAUBLE and MAC TOTUM in the Dreſs of a Banyan.

sp.speaker: Sir SOL.
sp.p: Mac Totum, ha! And you are no Indian, you ſay?

sp.speaker: MAC T.
sp.p: No, Sir ; but going to India very young, I learn'd their language, and paſs for a native.

sp.speaker: Sir SOL.
sp.p: That is, you are a kind of a mock-turtle among them ; ha, Mr. Mac Totum! And ſo, you are your maſter's banyan, eh! His interpreter, his ſecretary, his bookkeeper, his caſh-keeper, his ſecret-keeper, his ſcrub, his every thing, eh!

sp.speaker: MAC T.
sp.p: I ſee, Sir, to the diſcharge of all thoſe important truſts, either in perſon or by the appointment of his honour's other people ; for whoſe fidelity I am reſponſible ; ſuch as his dallals and darogas, vakeels and gomaſtahs, mutſeddees, chubdars and ſoontaburdars, down to his honour's, pykes, peons, and cooleys.

sp.speaker: Sir SOL.
sp.p: [Aſide] A conſequential kind of domeſtic truly! His dallals and darogas, mutſeddees, chubdars, pykes, peons and cooleys. Who, the devil, are all theſe?

sp.speaker: MAC T.
sp.p: They are his honour's agents, brokers, clerks, ſtewards, wand-bearers, torch-bearers, pedlars, porters and running footmen.

sp.speaker: Sir SOL.
sp.p: What a tribe of locuſts! Why 'tis a retinue for a S • bah.

sp.speaker: MAC T.
sp.p: And yet his honour, on the country eſtabliſhment, is at preſent only the Fowzdàr of a Chúcklah.

sp.speaker: Sir SOL.
sp.p: The Fowzdàr of a Chúcklah! A kind of Middleſex juſtice, if I remember right.

sp.speaker: MAC T.
sp.p: On his return to India, indeed, he will probably be made an Omrah.

sp.speaker: Sir SOL.
sp.p: An Omrah! What a Lord! Eh! —As to that, he might be made a Lord of here. But why this exhibition of eaſtern pompoſity in London?

sp.speaker: MAC T.
sp.p: Sir, his honour makes this diſplay of his Indian ſplendor, in order to induce the young lady, he is going to marry, to return more willingly with him to Bengal.

sp.speaker: Sir SOL.
sp.p: Nay, but ſo much ceremony with friends is troubleſome. I could find eaſier acceſs at St. James's—Is the Monarch of the Brititſh Empire more affable than the Fowzdar of a Chucklah?

sp.speaker: MAC T.
sp.p: His honour, Sir, notwithſtanding forms, is friendly and familiar. The Durbar, his levee, is by this time aſſembled, and you ſhall be uſhered into the Huzzoor, the preſence, immediately.

sp.speaker: Sir SOL.
sp.p: The Durbar! Huzzoor! Preſence! Egad, this Fowzdar of a Chucklah takes on him the ſtate of a great Mogul! [Exeunt.

div.head: SCENE III.
div.stage: The Scene opens and diſcovers Governor Mammon magnificently dreſſed, and lolling on a ſuperb Sofa—On each Side are ranged Black, Mulattoe and White Servants, in Eaſtern Habits and tawdry Liveries; ſome holding Branches of Wax-lights, others Silver Wands, ſhort Silver Staffs, &c. The Levee is compoſed of Jews, Armenians, Perſians and Europeans, variouſly habited.

sp.speaker: G. MAM.
sp.p: Munſhy Dives.

sp.speaker: DIVES.
sp.p: Your honour!

sp.speaker: G. MAM.
sp.p: Have you looked at that parcel of diamonds? what will you give?

sp.speaker: DIVES.
sp.p: Thirty thouſand pounds, your honour! They are large, but ſome of them are flawed and cloudy.

sp.speaker: G. MAM.
sp.p: They coſt me, three lacks of rupees : for two thouſand more they are yours.

sp.speaker: DIVES.
sp.p: Your honour ſhall have the monies.

sp.speaker: G. MAM.
sp.p: The emeralds, pearls and rubies. What ſay you to them?

sp.speaker: DIVES.
sp.p: Ten thouſand, your honour. I would not give more to my own brother.

sp.speaker: G. MAM.
sp.p: Transfer, receive and veſt the caſh in the funds.

sp.speaker: TRANSFER.
sp.p: India ſtock, your honour?

sp.speaker: G. MAM.
sp.p: What, man, are you mad? —South Sea— And when a ſnug bargain of terra firma offers, turn it into dirt—Land is a more valuable commodity than paper. — Lazarus!

sp.speaker: LAZ.
sp.p: Your honour!

sp.speaker: G. MAM.
sp.p: Thoſe cheſts of tea and raw ſilk—Are they ſafely run and diſpoſed of?

sp.speaker: LAZ.
sp.p: At your honour's own price.

sp.speaker: G. MAM.
sp.p: And the piece-goods, the coſſaes, cuſhtaes, callipaties, carridaries, dooſooties, jamdannies, mulmuls and mooſooroos!

sp.speaker: LAZ.
sp.p: All, your honour. —

sp.speaker: G. MAM.
sp.p: Place the money in the Bank. Their paper is as good as caſh. —Pandar!

sp.speaker: PANDAR.
sp.p: Your honour!

sp.speaker: G. MAM.
sp.p: In making proviſion for my Zenana, let me have no more brunettas. I would not give an anna for your dark-eyed moppetts. But, pay the mother of the fair wench I brought from Plymouth, a thouſand rupees, and ſettle upon the daughter a jaghire, at the rate of three hundred per month, during pleaſure. I ſhall not need your ſervice again perhaps this month. —I am going to be married.

div.stage: Enter Sir SOLOMON BAUBLE introduced by MAC TOTUM.

sp.speaker: MAC T.
sp.p: Sir Solomon Bauble, your honour! [Governor Mammon riſes from the ſofa and comes forward to embrace Sir Solomon, mean while the levee and ſervants go off.]

sp.speaker: G. MAM.
sp.p: Sir Solomon Bauble, I am proud to embrace you.

sp.speaker: Sir SOL.
sp.p: And I to return the compliment, Governor— Your Egyptian Princeſs—

sp.speaker: G. MAM.
sp.p: Is a diamond of the firſt ; water, you would ſay ; I knew her highneſs would charm you.

sp.speaker: Sir SOL.
sp.p: She has indeed, Governor ; and has captivated the hearts too of half a ſcore connoiſſeurs of my acquaintance already. I wiſh ſome of the rakiſh young dogs, among our virtuoſi, don't raviſh her from me. They plundered my cabinet of an ineſtimable Otho no longer ago than this very morning.

sp.speaker: G. MAM.
sp.p: I will ſupply its place, by the next ſhips, with an illegible coin of the Emperor Ting, Ving, Ching ; who reigned in China, ten thouſand years, before the creation.

sp.speaker: Sir SOL.
sp.p: You are very good, Governor. And if you could but procure me the genealogy of the Princeſs—a mummy without a genealogy is like a Welch woman without a pedigree.

sp.speaker: G. MAM.
sp.p: Faith, Sir Solomon, I can ſay little to that. I had her from a Baſhaw of three tails, at Mocho, in the Straits of Babel-mandel. If you want to know more of her, we muſt ſend to Mocho for information.

sp.speaker: Sir SOL.
sp.p: Egad, I ſhall be infinitely obliged to you, Governor. From a Baſhaw of three tails, at Mocho, in the Straits of Babel-mandel! Why, ſhe may be one of the daughters of King Pharoah, that was drowned in the Red Sea ; who knows?

sp.speaker: G. MAM.
sp.p: I can ſay nothing to the contrary, Sir Solomon— But to buſineſs—How does my contracted ſpouſe, your niece Emilia ; I intend to-morrow morning to pay my reſpects to her.

sp.speaker: Sir SOL.
sp.p: You will do her honour.

sp.speaker: G. MAM.
sp.p: Mean time, Sir Solomon, you will order the lawyers to adjuſt the neceſſary preliminaries to our wedding. I have ſpoken to Mr. Serjeant Nonplus, who will meet your Counſel about the marriage ſettlements. You will excuſe me at preſent ; I muſt attend the General Court. —What ho! without—my palanqueen there! [calls to his ſervants without ; whence is repeatedly heard "His honour's chair."] [Speaking to Sir Salomon.] Nay, no ceremony, good Sir Solomon—We'll go together. [Exeunt.

div.head: SCENE IV. Lord Lovemore's.
div.stage: Enttr Lord LOVEMORE and General GANTLET meeting.

sp.speaker: Lord LOVE.
sp.p: Good-morrow, General.

sp.speaker: G. GAN.
sp.p: Good day, my Lord, I am heartily glad to ſee you—What, it is all over, I ſuppoſe—How did the fellow behave?

sp.speaker: Lord LOVE.
sp.p: Over! what ſhould be over, General?

sp.speaker: G. GAN.
sp.p: Why, did not you call him out?

sp.speaker: Lord LOVE.
sp.p: Him! whom?

sp.speaker: G. GAN.
sp.p: The raſcal that affronted you laſt night at the whiſt table.

sp.speaker: Lord LOVE.
sp.p: I took no affront, General ; nor recollect any that was given me.

sp.speaker: G. GAN.
sp.p: No affront! Did not your partner tread on your toe the moment you were cut in!

sp.speaker: Lord LOVE.
sp.p: As we changed ſeats—An accident! He begged my pardon.

sp.speaker: G. GAN.
sp.p: An accident! Ha! did he not revoke in play?

sp.speaker: Lord LOVE.
sp.p: Miſplay'd a ſpade, I think—An overſight!

sp.speaker: G. GAN.
sp.p: An overſight! Did he not look aſkew at you all the evening?

sp.speaker: Lord LOVE.
sp.p: The gentleman, General, had the misfortune to have a caſt in his eye.

sp.speaker: G. GAN.
sp.p: A caſt! The misfortune! Eh! I would have caſt him into the pit of perdition, had he ſo ſquinted at me— A caſt! lookye, my Lord, if you think ſuch things to be put up with, it is no buſineſs of mine. My dignity will not ſuffer by it ; tho' my affinity to your Lordſhip, makes me ſolicitous for the preſervation of your honour.

sp.speaker: Lord LOVE.
sp.p: I am obliged to you, General ; but I am not ſo captious as to regard ſuch trifles in a ſerious light.

sp.speaker: G. GAN.
sp.p: Mighty well, my Lord! mighty well! Captious! Ha! Yes my Lord, I am captious and exceptious too, and you may think me capricious too, if your Lordſhip pleaſes; no matter, but while I have the honour to be your Lordſhip's brother-in-law, and have the character of a ſoldier to maintain, I will be tenacious too ; tenacious of the dignity of human nature, my Lord. And I ſay again, if any raſcal breathing had ſquinted at me as that fellow did laſt night at your Lordſhip, I would have tumbled him down the precipice of perdition! —And ſo Lord Lovemore, I bid your Lordſhip good day [turning round on his heel and ſtrutting off the ſtage.]

sp.speaker: G. GAN.
sp.p: [returning] I would my Lord, by all that is great in man [again turning round on his hecl and ſtrutting off ; His Lordſhip looking after him with a ſarcaſtical ſmile.]

sp.speaker: G. GAN.
sp.p: [again returning] You may ſmile, my Lord ; but I would have crumbled his ſoul to powder—to atoms, my Lord—to atoms—to atoms [ſhaking his cane and ſtalking magiſterially off the ſtage.]

sp.speaker: Lord LOVE.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha! If this madman's diſpoſition were not ſo miſchievous, it would be really entertaining. It is to be hoped, however, his phrenzy is of that kind it will ſoon work its own cure.

div.stage: Enter SERVANT.

sp.speaker: SERV.
sp.p: Captain Boothby, my Lord.

div.stage: Enter BOOTHBY.

sp.speaker: Lord LOVE.
sp.p: Did you meet the General, Boothby?

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: I came with him, my Lord, but, ſuppoſing he had buſineſs with your Lordſhip, I waited below till he retired.

sp.speaker: Lord LOVE.
sp.p: What can have poſſeſſed him, to day?

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: What always poſſeſſes him, my Lord. A ſpirit of contradiction.

sp.speaker: Lord LOVE.
sp.p: He would bring me into a quarrel here I know nothing of.

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: He has been taking up a buſineſs too, he ſays, of mine. But I neither know what it is, nor can I get it out of him.

sp.speaker: Lord LOVE.
sp.p: Then let him keep it to himſelf. The only good quality he has, is that of ſometimes keeping ſecret his own miſchief—How does Mrs. Boothby to day? You ſpend the evening with us.

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: Lady Lovemore will have company.

sp.speaker: Lord LOVE.
sp.p: A private party only ; we ſhall not play high.

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: Your Lordſhip is ſo obliging then as to pay attention to my finances.

sp.speaker: Lord LOVE.
sp.p: Faith I beg your pardon, Boothby, for the expreſſion ; ſuch attention is unneceſſary. I have as good as ſettled your preferment to-day. There will be ſoon a general promotion, and you are to have the regiment at Gibraltar.

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: You gave me hopes, my Lord, of being provided for in England.

sp.speaker: Lord LOVE.
sp.p: I did ſo ; but ſo many difficulties ſtood in the way, that, to prevent delays, I acquieſced, You will be recalled home in a year or two at moſt, ſo that it is much the ſame thing as if you were not to go.

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: I know not that, my Lord. In the predicament I ſtand with my father-in-law, my abſence, in the mean time, may prove prejudicial to my intereſt.

sp.speaker: Lord LOVE.
sp.p:
I can't ſee that—Mrs. Boothby will remain in England ; and perhaps effect a reconciliation the ſooner without you. I ſhall be ready to do her any ſervices in my
power ; and, if ſhe even chuſes a domeſtic protection, Lady Lovemore will, I am ſure, be happy in ſo agreeable a companion.

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: Your Lordſhip's friendſhip is ſo generouſly impoſing, that I ſhall ſubmit my conduct entirely to you, if I can prevail on Mrs. Boothby to acquit me of the promiſe I have made, to take her with me ſhould I be ordered abroad.

sp.speaker: Lord LOVE.
sp.p: Oh! ſhe is too reaſonable a woman to inſiſt on it. A wife, Boothby, is a very troubleſome meſs-mate, on ſhip-board and in a garriſon. But you will have time enough to reconcile her to ſo ſhort an abſence before you embark.

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: I ſhall, my Lord, but I cannot acquaint her too ſoon with the ſucceſs of your Lordſhip's negotiation. I therefore humbly take my leave. Your Lordſhip's obedient. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Lord LOVE.
sp.p: Your ſervant, Captain. —The wife of this Boothby muſt at any rate be mine. She is a charming woman. But they ſay ſhe is virtuous and loves her huſband. What a villain then am I to go about to ſeduce her? Yet why that queſtion! I may not ſucceed ; and mere intentional crimes are venial. I'll riſk the trial. By providing for the huſband, I ſecure an intereſt in the gratitude of the wife. Her affection for him ſhall plead for the love of her gallant. But, till it works effect, I muſt be diſtant and reſerved—It were as impolitic to alarm the modeſty of a woman, till ſome impreſſion be made on her heart, as for a General to give the ſignal to ſtorm till he had effected a breach— [Exit.

div.head: SCENE I. An Apartment at Sir Solomon Bauble's.
div.stage: Enter WITMORE and EMILIA.

sp.speaker: WIT.
sp.p: Almoſt a week in London, Emilia, and not let me hear from you! Not a line, or a meſſage, to adviſe me of your arrival!

sp.speaker: EM.
sp.p: If you knew, Sir, the reaſon of my coming to town, you would excuſe me. I have given you, perhaps, too much encouragement already.

sp.speaker: WIT.
sp.p: Too much encouragement, Emilia!

sp.speaker: EM.
sp.p: A young woman in my ſituation, Sir, ſhould have been more reſerved. You know the buſineſs, I ſuppoſe, on which Sir Solomon has ſent for you?

sp.speaker: WIT.
sp.p: Not particularly. Some law buſineſs, I find. I wiſh, my dear Emilia, you would give me leave to talk to him on a more intereſting ſubject.

sp.speaker: EM.
sp.p: What ſubject, Sir?

sp.speaker: WIT.
sp.p: Can you be at a loſs to gueſs, after the many kind aſſurances, you have flattered me with, of a partiality for me?

sp.speaker: EM.
sp.p: I hardly know what I have flattered you with, Mr. Witmore. But, whatever was my partiality for you, you ſhould have known that, a girl at my age had it not in her power to give herſelf away without the conſent of her relations.

sp.speaker: WIT.
sp.p:
Give me but your conſent to make openly my addreſſes, and I will do it immediately. Sir Solomon, I know, regards nothing ſo much as money. But, though at preſent my fortune is not very conſiderable, yet my connections and
expectations are ſuch, that I make no doubt of obtaining his conſent.

sp.speaker: EM.
sp.p: For heaven's ſake, huſh, I hear him hobbling down ſtairs. I have ſaid enough to pave the way. —You will ſoon know more than I have confidence to tell you. — [Exit.

div.stage: Enter Sir SOLOMON BAUBLE.

sp.speaker: Sir SOL.
sp.p: So, Mr. Witmore, you have been chatting with my niece Emmeline. She's a fine girl grown ; is not ſhe? ſhot up like an arrow! And I dare ſay you think her fit for a huſband.

sp.speaker: WIT.
sp.p: If ſhe thinks ſo herſelf, Sir Solomon. Miſs Emmeline is indeed grown a fine woman, and I doubt not would make an excellent wife.

sp.speaker: Sir SOL.
sp.p: You think ſo, eh! Witmore! Why to come to the point, then, it was on that ſubject I ſent to talk with you.

sp.speaker: WIT.
sp.p: You do me an honour, Sir Solomon, ſo young a lawyer is ſeldom thought entitled to. [aſide] What will this lead to? Surely ſhe has not broke the ice herſelf?

sp.speaker: Sir SOL.
sp.p: Why truly I have ſo good an opinion of you, Mr. Witmore, that I fixed my eye upon you as the moſt proper perſon I could think of. —I have been greatly obliged both to your talents and integrity.

sp.speaker: WIT.
sp.p: [aſide] 'Tis certainly ſo—ſhe ſaid ſhe had paved the way for me— [to Sir Solomon] Your partiality, Sir Solomon, over-rates my deſert.

sp.speaker: Sir SOL.
sp.p: Not at all—not at all. —I have heard the higheſt commendations of you from the gentlemen of your own profeſſion ; which is a good ſign ; a very good ſign, let me tell you, Mr. Witmore. You are, to be ſure, not yet at the head of it, but you are a young man, and in time will riſe perhaps to be Lord Chancellor—who knows?

sp.speaker: WIT.
sp.p: I am highly indebted to your good opinion of me, Sir Solomon.

sp.speaker: Sir SOL.
sp.p: Not a whit—not a whit—I declare again I ſhould not be aſhamed, were I the firſt baronet in the kingdom (which I am not by a great many.) I—

sp.speaker: WIT.
sp.p: You tranſport me, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir SOL.
sp.p: Nay, I proteſt, had I fifty nieces—

sp.speaker: WIT.
sp.p: Oh! Sir Solomon—

sp.speaker: Sir SOL.
sp.p: You ſhould draw up the marriage articles for every one of them, Mr. Witmore.

sp.speaker: WIT
sp.p: Sir! [turning away with marks of ſurprize and diſappointment.]

sp.speaker: Sir SOL.
sp.p: Sir! hey dey! why what's the matter, Barriſter? Is not the job worth your acceptance? I thought you would have ſeen to the making your friend Emilia's jointure ſecure, though you had done it without a fee.

sp.speaker: WIT.
sp.p: [confuſedly.] Jointure! fee! Sir Solomon! To be ſure I have a friendſhip for the young lady—but—hath ſhe made choice of a huſband?

sp.speaker: Sir SOL.
sp.p: She! poor young thing! How ſhould ſhe know how to make choice of a huſband? Oh! no. That trouble was taken off her hands ſome time ago. Her friends in India took care of that—Governor Mammon, who came over by the laſt ſhips, contracted two years ago to marry her, on his arrival in England, under the penalty of a lack of rupees; near twelve thouſand pounds ſterling. So that, you ſee, we have long had the huſband ſafe enough. We have now only to ſecure her dowry and pin-money.

sp.speaker: WIT.
sp.p: And the young lady abides by this ſame contract, I ſuppoſe.

sp.speaker: Sir SOL.
sp.p: I'll warrant her. Do you know, Sir, Governor Mammon is a nabob?

sp.speaker: WIT.
sp.p: [aſide] Then every woman is a jilt. [To Sir Sol.] Pardon me, Sir Solomon, I am taken ſuddenly with a kind of vertigo ; the effect of ſetting up over a difficult caſe laſt night.

sp.speaker: Sir SOL.
sp.p: Ah! the law! the law is a vertiginous kind of ſtudy. But come, ſit you down, ſit you down. Lady Bauble is not ſtirring yet, but Emmy ſhall give you a cordial. —I ſhall be back by the time you are recovered and have compoſed yourſelf— [aſide] mean time I'll go take one peep at her highneſs this morning. Here, who waits there? Where is Emmy? Emmy ſhall bring you a cordial, Mr. Witmore. [Exit.

sp.speaker: WIT.
sp.p: Why, what a fool have I been to be made thus the dupe of a child! a chit! a girl! —

div.stage: Enter EMILIA.

sp.speaker: EM.
sp.p: [running with looks of great concern] Bleſs me, Mr. Witmore, what's the matter?

sp.speaker: WIT.
sp.p: Matter! Miſs! I am too much aſhamed to tell you ; and yet I know not whether I ought to bluſh moſt for myſelf or you.

sp.speaker: EM.
sp.p: Cruel Mr. Witmore! Then you know my ſituation and have no pity for me. Would to Heaven I had never ſeen you!

sp.speaker: WIT.
sp.p: How can you juſtify yourſelf, madam?

sp.speaker: EM.
sp.p: I don't pretend to it, Sir. I confeſs I have been to blame ; but I hardly knew the force, or reflected on the conſequences of the contract I had ſigned, till you had taken advantage of my youth and inexperience, to rob me of a heart which I ought to have preſerved to give, where, they ſay, I muſt give my hand. If you love me as you have pretended, therefore, you will deviſe ſome method of delivering me from the bondage, to which the will of arbitrary and mercenary parents (for ſo I muſt call them) have deſtined me.

sp.speaker: WIT.
sp.p: And does my Emmeline, then, wiſh to be freed from her contract with Governor Mammon?

sp.speaker: EM.
sp.p: I deteſt, abhor the propoſed union. If therefore you can contrive any means to protract or prevent it, you may depend on the concurrence of your Emmeline.

sp.speaker: WIT.
sp.p: My Emmeline! Charming girl! thou ſhalt then ſtill be mine. [He runs to embrace her.

div.stage: Enter Sir SOLOMON.

sp.speaker: Sir SOL.
sp.p: Heyday! This is friendly indeed! What! —

sp.speaker: WIT.
sp.p: [ſoftly to Emm.] Sir Solomon! [aloud] Miſs Emmeline, I wiſh you joy of ſo happy an event, and will certainly take care the covenants ſhall be as binding as law can make them. [They part ceremoniouſly.

sp.speaker: Sir SOL.
sp.p: [aſide] O ho! is that all? Egad my mind began to miſgive me. [to Emm.] Ay, Emmy, Mr. Witmore takes part in our happineſs, and will therefore take care of our intereſt.

sp.speaker: EM.
sp.p: I then ſhall leave my concerns entirely with him, Sir ; but muſt beg he will take ſufficient time, to make every thing ſecure ; and proceed in nothing with precipitation. [Exit.

sp.speaker: WIT.
sp.p: You ſhall be obliged, madam ; even to the minuteſt punctilio of procraſtination.

sp.speaker: Sir SOL.
sp.p: Oh! no, Sir! No procraſtination! I have given my word of honour to the Governor, that the lawyers ſhall diſpatch their buſineſs without delay.

sp.speaker: WIT.
sp.p: That's impoſſible, Sir. A lawyer's diſpatch always admits of delay.

div.stage: Enter Lady BAUBLE.

sp.speaker: Lady BAU.
sp.p: What is that, Sir, you talk of delay? I beg nothing may be deferred, on any account whatever.

sp.speaker: WIT.
sp.p: There ſhall be no more delay than is neceſſary, madam. But a little procraſtination is always uſual on occaſions of this kind ; it looks like a regard for decorum on the part of the lady.

sp.speaker: Lady BAU.
sp.p: We muſt diſpenſe a little with decorum, Sir. The Governor muſt be complimented with a ſhort day. After ſuch handſome preſents! A moſt ſuperb ſet of ornamental china!

sp.speaker: Sir SOL.
sp.p: True wife ; and the mummy of an Egyptian Princeſs! —No, no procraſtination.

sp.speaker: Lady BAU.
sp.p: I think not : where's my niece? Wo'nt matrimony go down with her without procraſtination? Leave her to me, Sir Solomon—woman's wit in theſe caſes may do more than man's wiſdom—And do you, Mr. Witmore, conſult with Serjeant Nonplus, the Governor's counſel, and come both hither for more particular inſtructions immediately : do the buſineſs as ſecurely as poſſible ; and no procraſtination I beg of you. [Exit.

sp.speaker: WIT.
sp.p: I will obey you, madam. I ſhall juſt ſtep into Weſtminſter-Hall, to ſpeak to Serjeant Nonplus; and we will call upon you preſently. Sir Solomon, your ſervant. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Sir SOL.
sp.p: [in a kind of reverie] Your fervant, Sir—your ſervant—Ha! gone! Odſo, what a pity I let the barriſter go, without introducing him to the Princeſs. [Exit.

div.head: SCENE II. Capt. Boothby's Lodgings at Mrs. Goodwill's.
div.stage: Enter Mrs. BOOTHBY and Mrs. GOODWILL.

sp.speaker: Mrs. GOOD.
sp.p: I could, indeed, tell you ſuch ſtories of Lord Lovemore, madam.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BOOTH.
sp.p:
I am ſufficiently ſhocked at what I have heard already. —Indeed I beg your pardon, Mrs. Goodwill. I yeſterday thought you too cenſorious : but, after his Lordſhip's unguarded behaviour at his own houſe laſt night, I can
believe the worſt of him ; and indeed have not the beſt opinion of his Lady. Would you believe it, Mrs. Goodwill, he had the confidence to make down-right love to me, —to rail at Mr. Boothby, and even offer me his protection, in the very preſence of his wife. I find too that Mr. Boothby is to be promoted to the command of a regiment abroad.

sp.speaker: Mrs. GOOD.
sp.p: And have you told the Captain your ſuſpicions, madam?

sp.speaker: Mrs. BOOTH.
sp.p: I would not have him know them for the world. The conſequences would be fatal. But what ſhall I do? We are under an engagement to go to the maſquerade to night.

sp.speaker: Mrs. GOOD.
sp.p: To the maſquerade, madam! Indeed it requires conſideration. Strange doings have been carried on at maſquerades.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BOOTH.
sp.p: Strange doings, Mrs. Goodwill! You terrify me! —It is an entertainment I have the greateſt curioſity to be preſent at. But if there be any danger attending it, I proteſt, I will ſtay at home.

sp.speaker: Mrs. GOOD.
sp.p: That reſolution, madam, may perhaps too much alarm Captain Boothby.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BOOTH.
sp.p: That's true, and yet—But here they both come—I am ſo chagrined and perplexed, I know not what to do—Come, come and ſit with me awhile. —You muſt adviſe me— [Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Lord LOVEMORE and BOOTHBY.

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: A fit of the ſpleen, my Lord! Mere vapours! It went off immediately on her coming into the air.

sp.speaker: Lord LOVE.
sp.p: I am glad to hear that— [aſide] A good omen! ſhe has not yet told her huſband I ſind— [to Boothby] Why you were both the favourites of fortune. I thought no lady had the ſpleen while ſhe was winning at cards.

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: Mrs. Boothby has delicate nerves, my Lord ; and is little uſed to late hours and the card table. Your Lordſhip may have your revenge, however, at any time on me.

sp.speaker: Lord LOVE.
sp.p: I intend to have it on both, I aſſure you.

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: With all my heart, my Lord, when and where you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Lord LOVE.
sp.p: To morrow night then—to night you know we go to the maſquerade.

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: Be it ſo—

sp.speaker: Lord LOVE.
sp.p: [affecting a langh] Ha! ha! ha! Faith Boothby, thou art the happieſt fellow in the world—You have an angel of a woman for your wife. And ſo ſhe did not tell you the reaſon of her breaking away ſo ſuddenly laſt night. I muſt let you into the ſecret, leſt through miſtake ſhe think hardly of me.

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: Why ſo, my Lord?

sp.speaker: Lord LOVE.
sp.p: You muſt know, that to get rid of the effuſions of her gratitude, which ſhe took an opportunity to pour out on me, for the trouble I have taken to ſolicit your preferment, I, in raillery made love to her, by telling her how eaſily ſhe might get rid of the obligation.

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: And ſhe took you to be in earneſt. Ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Lord LOVE.
sp.p: Even ſo ; but it was in the preſence of Lady Lovemore, ſo that 'twas impoſſible I could mean any thing, you know.

sp.speaker: Lady LOVE.
sp.p: No, my Lord, I am very ſure you did not— You will excuſe Mrs. Boothby.

sp.speaker: Lord LOVE.
sp.p: Nay, you muſt make my excuſe to her. She left us ſo abruptly, that ſhe gave me no time to come to an explanation.

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: Will you apologize for yourſelf, my Lord? Mrs. Boothby is within.

sp.speaker: Lord LOVE.
sp.p: No, no, it will come better from you. I muſt away to the Secretary at war. To tell you the truth, I heard yeſterday of a vacancy at home, that may be worth your acceptance ; and therefore deſired an interview with him to day. If I ſucceed in your behalf, you ſhall know what it is. If it be already diſpoſed of (for there are innumerable ſolicitants) we will think of it as a gem long loſt, and watch the next opportunity of meeting with its fellow.

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: I am infinitely indebted to your Lordſhip, for this obliging attention to my intereſt.

sp.speaker: Lord LOVE.
sp.p: I only wiſh I may be able to ſerve you as I intend—But I muſt go—Mean time, do you hear, Boothby, make my peace with your wife before I ſee her again. [Exit.

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: I will, my Lord—How noble and generous is it in his Lordſhip to give himſelf all this trouble of application for me! —And yet—when I reflect on Mrs. Boothby's behaviour laſt night, and this whimſical tale of a love ſtory. —I don't half like it. His Lordſhip is a man of intrigue, and the liberties which men of rank think themſelves authorized to take, in this age of gallantry, with their inferiors, are alarming. I muſt ſpeak to Mrs. Boothby. But ſhe'll not be open enough to tell me, if there ſhould be any thing in it, left it ſhould breed a quarrel. —Phoo! hang it, it cannot be neither —in the preſence of his own wife! And ſhe one of the beſt and moſt amiable women in the univerſe! I am aſhamed of the ſuſpicion. —It is to the laſt degree injurious to ſo generous, ſo diſintereſted a friend. What a mean contracted heart is this of mine! I bluſh to think I am poſſeſſed of ſuch a narrow ſoul!

div.stage: Enter SERVANT introducing General GANTLET.

sp.speaker: SERV.
sp.p: General Gantlet, Sir. [Servant retires.

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: Good morrow, General.

sp.speaker: GAN.
sp.p: Good morrow, Boothby—You come off winner laſt night.

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: Unaccountably ſo. A novice among adepts and yet ſo fortunate.

sp.speaker: GAN.
sp.p: Adepts! Sharpers!

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: What mean you, General!

sp.speaker: GAN.
sp.p: The ſtranger in blue and gold gave you the game every time.

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: That was very obliging in a ſtranger, General. But I know no reaſon for it.

sp.speaker: GAN.
sp.p: Then I would make him give one. —Colonel Baſto aſſures me he has ſeen him at Bath, and knows him to be a common gambler. Lord Lovemore ſhould be called to account for introducing ſuch a ſcoundrel into company at his own houſe. —You know, in regard to my ſiſter, it would look ill in me, or elſe—But I'll carry him a civil meſſage for you.

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: To Lord Lovemore! My beſt friend! impoſſible to think of it, General. He muſt have been impoſed on, in the character of the gentleman. Or, if not, gamblers now get into the company of the firſt people in the kingdom.

sp.speaker: GAN.
sp.p: Not in private parties, at their own houſes, Sir. — However, you may do as you pleaſe—You may put up with it—But if any other perſon had introduced a fellow that bad taken the liberty to put his money into my pocket—

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: Nay but conſider, General, Lord Lovemore is my friend, my patron, and no very diſtant relation ; a man of high rank, and your brother-in-law—

sp.speaker: GAN.
sp.p: Were he the firſt Duke in the land, brother-in-law to any body but myſelf, Sir, here, here [holding open his fingers.] would I pillory his noſe—He ſhould breathe through theſe fingers, Sir, and breathe his laſt.

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: [aſide] I muſt give into the humour of this Goth ; or he may work himſelf to attack my Lord himſelf. [to Gen. Gantlet] Well then, General, to oblige you—

sp.speaker: GAN.
sp.p: Oblige me! Sir▪ Oblige yourſelf! ſupport your own dignity, Mr. Boothby.

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: I Will, General, and call his Lordſhip to account on the ſubject of laſt night, depend on it.

sp.speaker: GAN.
sp.p: Do my boy, that's a brave lad. Ever while you live, Boothby, ſupport your own dignity. [Exit ſtrutting magiſterially off the ſtage.

div.stage: Enter Mrs. BOOTHBY at the oppſite door in a fright.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BOOTH.
sp.p: Bleſs me, Mr. Boothby, what is it you have promiſed that ſavage General? What is it he has been adviſing you? Challenge Lord Lovemore! indeed, my dear, there, was nothing in the fooliſh affair of laſt night that ſhould excite ſuch reſentment. It was a capricious miſtake of my own. He could not mean any thing—Lady Lovemore herſelf was by and heard every word that was ſaid.

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: I know it, my dear. But why are you ſo much alarmed? The General is not in his dignity-ſtilts this morning upon your account.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BOOTH.
sp.p: Not on my account.

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: He took umbrage, it ſeems, at loſing his money laſt night, and would ſet every body quarrelling that was concerned in winning it.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BOOTH.
sp.p: [aſide] How have my curioſity and impatience betrayed me!

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: Nay, child, never mind it. You have only betrayed a little ſecret that I knew before. But why will you keep ſuch fooliſh ſecrets from me? A woman ſhould have no confidant in theſe matters but her huſband. Lord Lovemore is much mord open and ingenuous. He has confided in me already, and has been juſt now telling the whole ſtory.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BOOTH.
sp.p: [aſide] Specious deceiver! but I dare not expoſe him.

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: Indeed, my dear, if your error did not proceed from an amiable cauſe, in which I am ſo deeply intereſted, I ſhould think you greatly to blame. His Lordſhip is ſo noble, ſo generous a friend, that I would not diſoblige him for the world. Even common gratitude ſhould induce us to put the moſt favourable conſtruction on his behaviour. Would you believe that he is now gone to the Secretary at War, of his own accord, to ſolicit a poſt for me, which he hears is become vacant at home? He ſeems to take a concern in my intereſt as if it were his own.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BOOTH.
sp.p: [aſide] Artful villain! I can no longer bear it. [Exit burſting into tears.

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: Tears of gratitude! ſuſceptible creature! how will ſhe reproach herſelf now, for having harboured an unjuſt ſuſpicion of our beſt benefactor! Enter Lady LOVEMORE. Lady Lovemore! —What nobody waiting there?

sp.speaker: Lady LOVE.
sp.p: Nay, no ceremony, Sir. I came in without it, becauſe I would not diſturb Mrs. Boothby. I hope her laſt night's indiſpoſition is attended with no ill conſequences.

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: Your ladyſhip's ſolicitude is obliging. None at all, it appears to have been a mere capricio, as inſignificant as the innocent cauſe of it.

sp.speaker: Lady LOVE.
sp.p: As the cauſe of it, Mr. Boothby!

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: Yes, madam, my Lord has been here this morning, and has related to me the whole circumſtance.

sp.speaker: Lady LOVE.
sp.p: [affecting to laugh.] He! he! he! and was there ever any thing ſo ridiculous? You may think yourſelf a happy man, Mr. Boothby, in ſo good a wife ; but, I proteſt, if every married woman were as exceptious as Mrs. Boothby, there would be no keeping up converſation between people of faſhion of different ſexes, an hour together.

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: Your ladyſhip is perfectly in the right. Mrs. Boothby's behaviour was certainly too exceptious.

sp.speaker: Lady LOVE.
sp.p: Oh! prepoſterous! we muſt rally her out of this ruſtic prudery, or ſhe will be fit to keep company with nobody but yourſelf, Mr. Boothby. I muſt go and give her a lecture ; indeed I muſt teach her to think and act a little more like folks of this world. [Exit.

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: How eaſy, ſpirited, and engaging! Well, after all, though virtue be a jewel, it is like a diamond, which, of the firſt water, muſt yet be poliſhed before it diſplays its luſtre. How admirable is the behaviour of this Lady Lovemore! Mrs. Boothby has not leſs natural goodneſs of heart, or of native beauty ; but to how much more advantage would they appear if ſhe had her ladyſhip's artificial habit of diſplaying them. She will profit, I dare ſay, by ſo ſtriking an example. Indeed my wife is as fortunate in having acquired the friendſhip of Lady Lovemore, as I am in that of his Lordſhip! [Exit.

div.head: SCENE III. Sir Solomon Bauble's.
div.stage: Enter Serjeant NONPLUS and Mr. WITMORE. —The Serjeant dreſſed in his gown and coif.

sp.speaker: Ser. NON.
sp.p: An independent fortune when of age, and great expectations! ſay you, maſter Witmore? a lucky hit for a young fellow that has been no longer at the bar!

sp.speaker: WIT.
sp.p: With your aſſiſtance, Mr, Serjeant, I hope it will prove ſo.

sp.speaker: Ser. NON.
sp.p: Why, lookye, brother Witmore, Governor Mammon may be a good client ; ſo that, ſhould it afterwards come out that I aſſiſted you in this buſineſs—

sp.speaker: WIT.
sp.p: I will then ſacrifice the firſt good client, I have, to you, Mr. Serjeant.

sp.speaker: Ser. NON.
sp.p: I expect no leſs than that ſtroke of friendſhip— one good turn, you know—

sp.speaker: WIT.
sp.p: Deſerves another, Mr. Serjeant.

sp.speaker: Ser. NON.
sp.p: Nay, if by marrying, the young Lady you make your fortune and retire from the bar, you may give me all your intereſt too.

sp.speaker: WIT.
sp.p: I'll do it, Mr. Serjeant.

sp.speaker: Ser. NON.
sp.p: Yes, but I will have no hand in any thing but delay. There is no diſrepute in the law's delay. I would not do any thing diſreputable for the world. It will hurt me in my practice, master Witmore.

sp.speaker: WIT.
sp.p: Diſrepute and diſhoneſty, Mr. Serjeant, as you ſhrewdly hint, are two things. Our practice does not depend on our integrity, but on our reputation for it.

sp.speaker: Ser. NON.
sp.p: A juſt diſtinction! True, character, character is all. You may do what you will if you be but artful or lucky enough to preſerve your character.

sp.speaker: WIT.
