sp.p: And if that be neglected, or unluckily loſt, be as honeſt as one will, it will ſignify nothing.

sp.speaker: Ser. NON.
sp.p: Egad, Mr. Witmore, for a young man, you ſeem to know a good deal of the world. It is almoſt a pity the bar ſhould loſe ſo promiſing a caſuiſt. You would make a figure at niſi prius and pleas of the crown.

sp.speaker: WIT.
sp.p: You flatter me, Mr. Serjeant. But young adventurers at the bar, like ſoldiers of fortune in arms, ſhould loſe no fair opportunity of advancing themſelves out of the line of their profeſſion.

sp.speaker: Ser. NON.
sp.p: Egad that's true—a fortune's a fortune : no matter how we come by it, as our old friend Horace ſays, Rem facias. Rem—quocunque modo Rem.

sp.speaker: WIT.
sp.p: Ay, Mr. Serjeant, that Rem is the thing—but I ſee the young lady coming this way. —If you will juſt walk into that room, I'll be with you preſently.

div.stage: [Exit Serjeant.
Enter EMILIA.

sp.speaker: EM.
sp.p: Well, Mr. Witmore, I have conſidered of your ſcheme. But I am afraid I ſhall not be able to ſet governor Mammon ſo much againſt me as to make him refuſe to fulfill the contract.

sp.speaker: WIT.
sp.p: Well, at the worſt, he cannot compell you to fulfil it. It is an adjudged caſe, that the marriage-contract of a minor is not binding. But never fear! play but your part with diſcretion, my dear Emily, and you cannot fail to deter him from the match. Repel his firſt attacks with vivacity and you ſhall find me, and Serjeant Nonplus, who is within, ready to compleat his repulſe.

sp.speaker: EM.
sp.p: —I would fain have the refuſal come from him— And yet—

sp.speaker: WIT.
sp.p: Nay, my dear Emmeline, ſtart no more objections —I thought I had fully ſatisfied your ſcruples, when you ſatisfied mine. Love knows no bonds, no ſhackles but what it impoſes on itſelf. It diſdains the formal reſtrictions impoſed on it by others, and ſubmits to no obligations but thoſe of the heart.

sp.speaker: EM.
sp.p: [ſmiling] But is this law, Mr. Witmore.

sp.speaker: WIT.
sp.p: The law of love, my dear Emmeline, which is the law of liberty.

sp.speaker: EM.
sp.p: And is there nothing inequitable in the caſe, eh!

sp.speaker: WIT.
sp.p:
Why to ſay truth, there is ſome little difference between law and equity in moſt caſes. But the court of love, my dear Emmeline, is a court of common law, and is governed
by ancient cuſtoms and uſages time immemorial ; of which none is of longer ſtanding than that of a woman's changing her mind. We ſhall certainly carry our point, therefore, at law ; which will put me in poſſeſſion of your charms, and then let equity diſpoſeſs me of them if it can.

sp.speaker: EM.
sp.p: How lucky it is that I have fallen into the hands of ſo great a lawyer! [Exeunt.

div.head: SCENE I. Sir Solomon Bauble's.
div.stage: Enter Governor MAMMON and Lady BAUBLE.

sp.speaker: Lady BAU.
sp.p: With a due reciprocation of civilities, Sir, I muſt needs ſay that your actions beſpeak it. There is, indeed, a generoſity in your behaviour, that hath charmed us all, except my niece Emmeline. I cannot think what's come to the girl ; but ſhe's grown quite hypocondriac, as I tell her.

sp.speaker: G. MAM.
sp.p: Thoughtful, perhaps, on her approaching change of condition, Madam!

sp.speaker: Lady BAU.
sp.p: Or perhaps, Governor, ſhe expected a preſent, as well as Sir Solomon and myſelf. We women are all a little mercenary, you know. And beſides ſhe might think it a mark of diſreſpect that ſhe had none. One cannot tell— theſe young things, who know but a little of the world, have ſtrange conceptions.

sp.speaker: G. MAM.
sp.p: I ſhould be ſorry, Madam, that Miſs Emmeline's inexperience ſhould cauſe her to cenſure me for want of reſpect ; but I reſerved ſuch teſtimony of my regard for her, till I ſhould have the honour of preſenting it myſelf. This caſket of diamonds—

sp.speaker: Lady BAU.
sp.p:
And have you brought her a caſket of diamonds then? Oh ſhe'll brighten up at the diamonds, I'll warrant her. I'll ſend her to you immediately. —But here ſhe is.
Enter EMILIA. Come, niece Emmeline, here is Governor Mammon, that is to be your huſband, you know, [taking hold of her band and leading her toward the Governor, who advances to ſalute her.] As you muſt have a great deal to ſay to one another, I leave you together, Governor, [aſide] I long to have their confabulation over, that I may contemplate the beauty of the diamonds. [Exit.

sp.speaker: G. MAM.
sp.p: [bowing as he retires from faluting her.] Miſs Emmeline, your ſlave— [aſide] a fine girl grown, faith, [to her.] You will permit me to preſent you with this token of my reſpect, before I enter on the ſubject of my love, [taking a caſket out of his pocket and preſenting it to her.]

sp.speaker: EM.
sp.p: [putting aſide the caſket with her hand.] By no means, Sir. Before I receive any preſent from you, Governor, it is proper I ſhould know what return I can make you.

sp.speaker: G. MAM.
sp.p: There needs no return, Madam.

sp.speaker: EM.
sp.p: True, Governor, if I become your wife, in which caſe your preſent is a mere piece of gallantry : and you may almoſt as well take it out of one hand and put it into the other. You ſtile yourſelf my ſlave : but rather call me your's; for I am certain you think ſo.

sp.speaker: G. MAM.
sp.p: Miſs Emmeline!

sp.speaker: EM.
sp.p: Nay, Sir, be not ſurprized. I am not now, Governor, the poor, ſimple girl, that was prevailed on to enter into a contract with you in India ; of which I have but lately underſtood the impropriety.

sp.speaker: G. MAN.
sp.p: Indeed, Madam, there ſeems to be a great alteration, both in your perſon and ſentiments. But as I admire the one, I preſume the other will make no alteration in the nature of our connexion.

sp.speaker: EM.
sp.p:
A groundleſs hope, Governor. To be plain with you, I find that women educated in England, not only beſtow
their perſons in marriage ; but that they have minds alſo, which are intereſted in the event of that union ; ſouls, Governor ; of which you Aſiatic tyrants will hardly allow us women to boaſt the poſſeſſion.

sp.speaker: G. MAM.
sp.p: Why really, Miſs Emmeline, you ſeem to be poſſeſſed of a ſoul indeed, if one may judge by this ſpecimen of your ſpirit. But as the philoſophers hold the ſoul to be of no ſex, we Aſiatics, as you call us, wiſely think the beſt part of a woman is her perſon.

sp.speaker: EM.
sp.p: And you would be mean enough to accept the hand of a woman, who had diſpoſed of her heart to another

sp.speaker: G. MAM.
sp.p: Why look ye, madam, if a woman takes upon her to diſpoſe of what is not her property, but has been made over to another, I don't ſee why the firſt owner may not, without the imputation of meanneſs, reclaim it. But is that really the caſe Miſs Emmeline.

sp.speaker: EM.
sp.p: Indeed, governor it is.

sp.speaker: G. MAM.
sp.p: Then you have dealt diſingenuouſly by me madam, [putting the caſket into his pocket.

sp.speaker: EM.
sp.p: How ſo, Sir? If all you require of a woman be the poſſeſſion of her perſon, what matters it on whom ſhe beſtows her affections!

sp.speaker: G. MAM.
sp.p: I looked on both in you as equally my property.

sp.speaker: EM.
sp.p: Why there, Sir! —it is juſt as I ſaid—You look upon me as your property, your purchaſed ſlave ; and would doubtleſs treat me as ſuch, were we married. You would be for taking me back to India, to make up the number of your Zenana, your ſeraglio of female favorites. But that is not in your power, Sir, were I even married to you, without my own conſent. And be aſſured I ſhall never willingly leave a country in which the privileges of our ſex are ſo well reſpected and ſecured. An Engliſh wife Governor—

sp.speaker: G. MAM.
sp.p: Is as great a tyrant—

sp.speaker: EM.
sp.p: As an Eaſtern huſband.

sp.speaker: G. MAM.
sp.p: Indeed!

sp.speaker: EM.
sp.p: She may at leaſt ſet her huſband's tyranny at defiance and repay his neglect of her in kind. So beware, Governor, what you do ; and as you approve the hint precipitate our nuptials. [Exit.

sp.speaker: G. MAM.
sp.p: Hey day! what a termagant young devil it is grown! Yes, yes, ſhe returned to England, to finiſh her education with a vengeance! No, no madam, I'll not marry, to go back to India and leave you in England neither. If I do marry you I will certainly get divorced before I go or compell you to go with me. —The privileges of an Engliſh wife truly! Repay their neglect in kind! What a poor devil is an Engliſh huſband!

div.stage: Enter WITMORE and Serjeant NONPLUS from within.

sp.speaker: Ser. NON.
sp.p: Governor, your ſervant.

sp.speaker: G. MAM.
sp.p: Well met, Mr. Serjeant—Egad you are luckily encountered here, I muſt have a little of your advice, or my young Tartar from Bengal will prove too much for me.

sp.speaker: Ser. NON.
sp.p: What's the matter, Sir?

sp.speaker: G. MAM.
sp.p: This morning, you know, I conſulted you about the ſhorteſt method of fulfilling a certain matrimonial contract. And now, I believe, I muſt conſult you on the ſhorteſt way of diſſolving it.

sp.speaker: Ser. NON.
sp.p: So ſuddenly Sir?

sp.speaker: WIT.
sp.p: What on the firſt interview, Governor?

sp.speaker: G. MAM.
sp.p: Why, the yonng lady ſpeaks her mind ſo plainly, that I've no need of a ſecond.

sp.speaker: Ser. NON.
sp.p: She is not to your fancy then Governor?

sp.speaker: G. MAM.
sp.p: Or rather I am not to hers. She has taken a fancy to ſomebody elſe it ſeems.

sp.speaker: WIT.
sp.p: And did ſhe own it to you?

sp.speaker: G. MAM.
sp.p: Yes faith ſhe was explicit enough in all conſcience. I cannot complain of her reſerve. You muſt find out ſome way, therefore, gentlemen to diſſolve this ſame contract.

sp.speaker: WIT.
sp.p: Impoſſible, Governor, without fulfilling the condition of the obligation.

sp.speaker: G. MAM.
sp.p: What muſt I be married to ſuch a ſhrew againſt my will?

sp.speaker: WIT.
sp.p: O, no, Sir, on the payment of a lack of Rupees you may be excuſed. Theſe are the terms of the contract, as I take it.

sp.speaker: G. MAM.
sp.p: Yes, but, as I take it, that forfeiture is too conſiderable. I'll marry her tho' it be to have the pleaſure of divorcing her the next day.

sp.speaker: WIT.
sp.p: True Governor if that pleaſure might be ſo ſoon had.

sp.speaker: G. MAM.
sp.p: May it not? I underſtood divorces were now become as frequent in England, as in the Eaſt.

sp.speaker: Ser. NON.
sp.p: They are pretty frequent indeed, Governor, and when the parties are agreed, are eaſily brought about. But if either be refractory, they are ſomewhat dilatory and expenſive.

sp.speaker: G. MAM.
sp.p: And pray, Gentlemen, in what time and expence upon an average now, may a man by the laws of England, get rid of a refractory wife.

sp.speaker: WIT.
sp.p: By the law of reaſon and therefore by the laws of England, Sir, it ſhould be very ſoon.

sp.speaker: Ser. NON.
sp.p: But, by the practice of them it cannot be at all.

sp.speaker: G. MAM.
sp.p: How Sir?

sp.speaker: Ser. NON.
sp.p: Even ſo Sir, a new law muſt be expreſsly made for that purpoſe.

sp.speaker: WIT.
sp.p: By that means it may be brought about.

sp.speaker: G. MAM.
sp.p: Well, no matter for the means, the time and expence.

sp.speaker: Ser. NON.
sp.p: Let me fee—The time and expence! — Crim. con. we muſt take for granted.

sp.speaker: G. MAM.
sp.p: Ay, ay, in all appearance we ſhall want no no proof of that.

sp.speaker: Ser. NON.
sp.p: An action may be proſecuted in the Temporal Court a reaſonable time and a moderate expence ; brother Witmore.

sp.speaker: WIT.
sp.p: Yes, yes; we common lawyers have ſome conſcience.

sp.speaker: Ser. NON.
sp.p: Verdict obtained at Weſtminſter, we go into the commons. A libel is inſtituted—recrimination enſues—

sp.speaker: G. MAM.
sp.p: Recrimination! What's that? Mr. Serjeant.

sp.speaker: Ser. NON.
sp.p: The recrimination of the canoniſts, Sir, is the antecatagory of the civilians.

sp.speaker: G. MAM.
sp.p: It is! Oh, ho! that makes every thing very plain.

sp.speaker: WIT.
sp.p: You muſt know, Governor, our canoniſts maintain that a woman may as lawfully go aſtray from her huſband as a man from his wife.

sp.speaker: G. MAM.
sp.p: The devil!

sp.speaker: WIT.
sp.p: Yes Sir, and our married women of courſe, play the devil on the authority.

sp.speaker: Ser. NON.
sp.p: Pope Boniface the 8th, Sir, as the prieſts had no wives of their own, indulgently promulgated this doctrine, for them to preach to the wives of others.

sp.speaker: G. MAM.
sp.p: But what have we to do with Pope Boniface or his indulgencies?

sp.speaker: Ser. NON.
sp.p: More than you may imagine, Governor. The reformatio legum not taking place the papal cannons continue ſtill in force, and Si quando mulier maritum—but perhaps I had better ſpeak plain Engliſh—

sp.speaker: G. MAM.
sp.p: By all means, Mr. Serjeant, if you can. — As you are upon a matter of importance, I ſhould be glad to underſtand you.

sp.speaker: Ser. NON.
sp.p: Then, Sir, to put the caſe familiarly, thus. If Jack A. being lawfully married to Jill B. peradventure Jill ſhould prove a jade (as, now a days, it is ten to one but ſhe does) yet, nevertheleſs and notwithſtanding, if the ſaid Jill make it appear that the ſaid Jack is as bad as herſelf ; it is in ſuch caſe to be adjudged, that the parties Jack and Jill are well matched, and it were a ſin to ſeparate ſo worthy a couple.

sp.speaker: G. MAM.
sp.p: Confound the pope and all his adherents!

sp.speaker: Ser. NON.
sp.p: With all my heart Governor ; except out brethren in the commons; with whom to proceed. —

sp.speaker: WIT.
sp.p: Ay, ay proceed, proceed Mr. Serjeant.

sp.speaker: Ser. NON.
sp.p: Recrimination ended. —Alimony ſettled. — Term probatory over go to trial. —Caſt! no matter which ſide, the huſband pays coſts on both.

sp.speaker: G. MAM.
sp.p: The devil! he does!

sp.speaker: WIT.
sp.p: Ay, Governor, there's the devil again.

sp.speaker: Ser. NON.
sp.p:
An appeal is next lodged in the Arches. — the ground gone over again. —Thence an appeal to the Delegates a definitive ſentence is obtained. This being in
your favour, on ſettling a handſome ſeparate maintenance on your wife you turn her off a menſa et thoro.

sp.speaker: G. MAM.
sp.p: And ſo get fairly rid of her, ha!

sp.speaker: WIT.
sp.p: Not ſo faſt, Governor ; only from bed and board.

sp.speaker: Ser. NON.
sp.p: Beſides, Sir, unleſs you fly the country, your Lady, if ſhe be induſtrious, may bring you a numerous family of well-begotten children ; to all of which you would be the only lawful father.

sp.speaker: G. MAM,
sp.p: Zounds! Gentlemen can this be law?

sp.speaker: WIT.
sp.p: Sound law, I aſſure you, Governor.

sp.speaker: Ser. NON.
sp.p: Ay, ay, found law! found law! —But, to go on with Our proceſs—

sp.speaker: G. MAM.
sp.p: Oh! confound its prolixity.

sp.speaker: Ser. NON.
sp.p: With ſentence for ſeparation a menſa et thoro, Governor, we go next into parliament for a divorce a vinculo matrimonii, the laſt ſtage.

sp.speaker: WIT.
sp.p: Where you may carry your point.

sp.speaker: G. MAM.
sp.p: Hell and the devil! what a proceſs!

sp.speaker: Ser. NON.
sp.p: Let me ſee! Brother Witmore, ay, on a moderate computation, in about ten years and at the expence of twenty, ay twenty, or one and twenty, thouſand pounds, the Governor may fairly get rid of his wife—that is, as I ſaid before crim. con. taken for granted.

sp.speaker: WIT.
sp.p: So you ſee, Governor, you may marry her as ſoon as you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: G. MAM.
sp.p: And ſo I will, though cuckoldom be my portion, if I cannot get rid of her, without ſuing for a divorce. You may proceed therefore, gentlemen, with the ſettlements : Yes, I'll marry her and ſhip her for India immediately, or perhaps ſhip her firſt, leſt ſhe ſhould give me the ſlip and run off with her lover. [Exit.

div.stage: The Lawyers look at each other with confuſion.

sp.speaker: WIT.
sp.p: Ha!

sp.speaker: Ser. NON.
sp.p: How's this brother Witmore? What cauſe have we been pleading here?

sp.speaker: WIT.
sp.p: Ship her for India, ſaid he! Egad, we muſt demur immediately, Mr. Serjeant. It will be too late to bring a writ of error after execution. Let us go to chambers and conſult.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: NON. Oh! a demurrer! a demurrer! by all means, Maſter Witmore, a demurrer. [Exeunt.

div.head: SCENE II. Boothby's Lodgings.
div.stage: Enter Lady LOVEMORE and Mrs. GOODWILL.

sp.speaker: Lady LOVE.
sp.p: Mrs. Boothby gone abroad, ſay you!

sp.speaker: Mrs. GOOD.
sp.p: To Pritchards, to give orders for her habit, madam.

sp.speaker: Lady LOVE.
sp.p: Oh! I ſhall then meet with her ten to one in my round. If not, tell her I ſhall call to take her with me in the evening. I muſt run away immediately. [Going out is met by General Gantlet.]

sp.speaker: GAN.
sp.p: [ſtopping her] Don't put yourſelf in a fluſter, ſiſter. I am ſorry for your Ladyſhip's ſituation! but theſe things will happen.

sp.speaker: Lady LOVE.
sp.p: Happen, General! —What will happen!

sp.speaker: GAN.
sp.p: Nay, madam, I thought by your flurry you had heard more than I—But if you have heard nothing, and will promiſe me not to be frightened, I will tell you.

sp.speaker: Lady LOVE.
sp.p: Promiſe not to be frightened—You have frightened me to death already. But indeed you are always terrifying me with ſome diſaſter or other. What's the matter now?

sp.speaker: GAN.
sp.p: Nay, it may come to nothing, therefore it is time enough to be alarmed—Mrs. Goodwill!

sp.speaker: Mrs. GOOD.
sp.p: Sir.

sp.speaker: GAN.
sp.p: What time did Mr. Boothby go out?

sp.speaker: Mrs. GOOD.
sp.p: I cannot exactly ſay the hour, Sir. But it was ſoon after you left him this morning. Lord Lovemore called in again, and they went out together.

sp.speaker: GAN.
sp.p: As I thought. That is two or three hours ago. Mr. Boothby, you find ſiſter, is not returned ; and I am juſt come from your houſe, where they know nothing of his Lordſhip ; ſo that it is plain one or both of them muſt have dropped.

sp.speaker: Lady LOVE.
sp.p: Dropped! Lord Lovemore or Mr. Boothby! Heaven and earth! Was there any quarrel between them?

sp.speaker: GAN.
sp.p: Quarrel, madam! Was it not unavoidable after the affair of laſt night.

sp.speaker: Mrs. GOOD.
sp.p: So this raſh General has been fomenting miſchief and ſtirring up ſtrife again!

sp.speaker: Lady LOVE.
sp.p: And what, brother, had you to do with the affair of laſt night?

sp.speaker: GAN.
sp.p: I will not ſuffer the honour of my friends, madam, to be hurt by their puſillanimity. And while I have that of being your huſband's brother-in-law, he ſhall neither give nor take an affront, if I can help it, without reſenting or being called to account for it.

sp.speaker: Lady LOVE.
sp.p: Your notions of honour, brother, are ridiculous. Is it leſs diſhonourable for a man to cut his friend's throat, than to be civil to his wife?

sp.speaker: GAN.
sp.p: I am an old batchelor, you know, and know nothing about wives. But if Boothby has not cut your huſband's throat for the inſult offered him at your houſe laft night, he is a—

sp.speaker: Lady LOVE.
sp.p:
And ſo you have been ſetting them to ſighting, I find. Oh, I ſhall faint! I ſhall die! My poor Lord is certainly
killed! He is murdered. [She throws herſelf into the chair and affects to faint away.]

sp.speaker: Mrs. GOOD.
sp.p: [running to her aſſiſtance, and taking ſmelling bottle from her pocket.] Help! help! here. —Pray, General, lay hold of the Lady's hand and keep it open.

sp.speaker: GAN.
sp.p: Me! not I madam! I know nothing of palmiſtry.

sp.speaker: Mrs. GOOD.
sp.p: Bleſs me, General : how could you go to frighten my Lady in this manner!

sp.speaker: GAN.
sp.p: Poh! frightened! If his Lordſhip be killed, he dies like a man of honour, and ſhe may the ſooner get another huſband.

sp.speaker: Lady LOVE.
sp.p: [recovering] Talk not to me brother of another huſband! I ſhall never live to ſupport the loſs of this!

div.stage: Enter BOOTHBY.

sp.speaker: GAN.
sp.p: Ha! Boothby! [turns on his heel and walks to the back of the ſtage.]

sp.speaker: Lady LOVE.
sp.p: Oh, Mr. Boothby! where—where is my poor Lord? barbarous man! have you indeed then left him dead, or ſhall I ſee him again alive? [throwing herſelf again into the chair.]

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: [aſide] So! ſo! ſo! Honour and dignity has been making fine work of it here, I find! [to Lady Lovemore] Your poor Lord, madam! I left him rich, alive and well not five minutes ago, turning over the habits at Pritchard's.

sp.speaker: Lady LOVE.
sp.p: Heaven be praiſed!

sp.speaker: Mrs. GOOD.
sp.p: So ſay I, my Lady. Let me beg of your Ladyſhip to compoſe yourſelf. You ſee nothing has happened that ſhould thus diſtreſs you.

sp.speaker: GAN.
sp.p: [having taken Boothy aſide] So, nothing came of it! Ha! —what! diſarm'd! —A ſcratch only, Eh! —Egad I wiſh I had ſaid nothing about it.

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: I believe, indeed, it had been better, General.

sp.speaker: Lady LOVE.
sp.p: [riſing from her chair] Inhuman brother! Why! why will you be thus perpetually frightening me? You had better draw your ſword and pierce my boſom at once than be thus ever terrifying me with falſe alarms.

sp.speaker: GAN.
sp.p: Fire and furies! madam! draw upon a woman! I that have dared death and deſtruction at the head of a line of battle! What effeminacy have you ever ſeen in me, madam, to think I ſhould contaminate my ſword with the blood of a woman? It is well, madam, it is not your huſband that inſults me thus. If he had, I would have wrung off his neck, as I would that of a turkey-cock. Draw my ſword on a woman! —But 'tis a woman's inſult, and ſo I put up with the indignity. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Lady LOVE.
sp.p: Bleſs me, Mr. Boothby, this brother of mine is quite frantic. Is there no method of curing this ridiculous folly.

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: I am afraid not, madam ; but I'll make a trial. I fancy I could frighten him as much as he has frightened your Ladyſhip.

sp.speaker: Lady LOVE.
sp.p: Would you could, Captain Boothby ; it would give me great ſatisfaction and might have ſome good effect on him ; for really his caprices are dreadful.

div.stage: Enter SERVANT with a Letter for BOOTHBY.

sp.speaker: SERV.
sp.p: A letter, Sir—the bearer ſaid it required no anſwer, but muſt be given into your hands immediately.

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: Your Ladyſhip will excuſe me.

sp.speaker: Lady LOVE.
sp.p: No apology Mr. Boothby—buſineſs muſt be minded—I muſt hurry away to aſſiſt Mrs. Boothby in the choice of her dreſs.

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p:
Your Ladyſhip's humble ſervant. [Exit Lady LOVEMORE.
Now let me ſee. [reads]
To Capt. Boothby —
If Captain Boothby would prevent his wife's ruin and preſerve his own honour, he will hinder her going to the maſquerade with Lord Lovemore, or when there will moſt carefully watch the behaviour of his Lordſhip.
The hand-writing is a woman's, and reſembles that of Lady Lovemore ; but it cannot be hers—ſhe is to accompany my wife, and therefore would hardly diſſuade me from letting her go. Beſides, ſhe ſeems not to have the leaſt tincture of jealouſy in her diſpoſition—Yet now I reflect ; come this notice from whom it will, it may not be proper to neglect it. Mrs. Boothby's conduct is myſterious. Her reſentment laſt night at Lord Lovemore's was unaffected and natural. And, though the paſſed off the matter ſlightly to day, the manner in which ſhe did it was neither eaſy nor natural—There may be ſomething more in this buſineſs than I am aware of. I will take Mrs. Boothby to taſk roundly for her reſerve. I'll make her believe I know more than I do, that ſhe may tell me more than I know. — Here ſhe comes. Enter Mrs. BOOTHBY.
Come hither madam. I have ſomething to ſay to you—but firſt let me ſhut the door.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BOOTH.
sp.p: Something to ſay to me! and ſuch preparation, it muſt be of importance ſure, Mr. Boothby.

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: It is madam. Tell me, Mrs. Boothby [taking her haſtily by the hand] and tell me truly, as you value my future quiet and your own happineſs, have you dealt fairly by me?

sp.speaker: Mrs. BOOTH.
sp.p: Bleſs me, Mr. Boothby, what do you mean? You terrify me to death by this earneſtneſs. Dealt fairly by you?

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: Ay, fairly, Mrs. Boothby.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BOOTH.
sp.p: Witneſs Heaven! that I have done it ever.

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: Nay, call not Heaven to witneſs a falſehood— You have deceived me Mrs. Boothby—You have treacherouſly concealed from me a ſecret, which I ought to have known, and which, had I not by other means diſcovered it, might have proved our ruin.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BOOTH.
sp.p: Of what falſehood? What deceit? What treachery have I been guilty?

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: You told me to day, that you thought Lord Lovemore meant nothing by the behaviour you reſented laſt night.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BOOTH.
sp.p: Unkind Mr. Boothby! did not you yourſelf ſay every thing to perſuade me ſo? Did you not ſay that gratitude for the obligations his Lordſhip ſought to confer on us, required the moſt favourable conſtruction to be put on his actions!

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: Obligations, madam! had he laid obligations on me till he had raiſed pile to reach the ſkies, the favour he ſought to confer by your means, would have tumbled them all down, and buried them in oblivion. —It is in vain to conceal It any longer. This letter, this letter, madam, has given me damnable intimations of the favours intended us.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BOOTH.
sp.p: By all my hopes of happineſs, both here and hereafter, I declare I have concealed nothing from you, but out of motives of the moſt ſincere fidelity and affectionate tenderneſs. I knew you to be ſo jealous of your honour, that I dreaded the fatal conſequences of telling you all.

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p:
And are not you, madam, equally jealous of my honour, that out of ſuch miſtaken tenderneſs for my perſonal
ſafety, you would betray the moſt invaluable treaſure of my ſoul? I Would you from ſo weak a motive ſubject me to be pointed at as the credulous dupe, the eaſy fool, the wittol of a titled raſcal whom I careſs as a friend.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BOOTH.
sp.p: Indeed, indeed you wrong me, Mr. Boothby. Heaven forbid I ſhould be put to the trial ; but I think I could. ſacrifice every thing I hold moſt dear to the preſervation of your honour.

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: As far as it is dependent on your fidelity, you may think it ſafe. The worſt even a bad woman can do is to make herſelf ridiculous, it is on herſelf only that ſhe can entail infamy. But men of honour, madam, have a degree of it to maintain, ſuperior to that which is in a woman's keeping.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BOOTH.
sp.p: I underſtand you not.

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: I will myſelf, madam, be the guardian both of my own honour and of yours. I have before told you a woman's beſt confidant is her huſband.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BOOTH.
sp.p: Will you then promiſe to command your temper, and not be urged by that of others to violence.

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: I will.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BOOTH.
sp.p: Then will I poſitively confide in you ; and ſhould his Lordſhip make any farther advances, acquaint you with it. And now, my dear, let me know the contents of that letter.

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: Read it [gives Mrs. Boothby the letter, and looks at her attentively while ſhe reads it]. Well, madam, what think you of it?

sp.speaker: Mrs. BOOTH.
sp.p: I think it is the contrivance of a very artful and a very jealous woman.

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: My Lady Lovemore!

sp.speaker: Mrs. BOOTH.
sp.p:
It is her hand—though purpoſely diſguiſed —I am ſure of it. I was before this almoſt tempted to
think her baſe enough to countenance the gallantries of her huſband.

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: Impoſſible! with her you are ſafe, whatever be the deſigns of his Lordſhip.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BOOTH.
sp.p: Then you would have me ſtill go to the maſquerade.

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: By all means; we cannot with any kind of decency break the appointment without breaking at once with Lord Lovemore ; which neither good manners nor prudence will yet juſtify.

Mrs. BOOTH. I will then go in to dreſs. Pritchard has promiſed to ſend me the habit, you ſo much admired to day. [Exit. Manet BOOTHBY.
How looſe are the principles of men of intrigue! And how often do we attribute, to motives of humanity and generoſity, a conduct influenced by the deſire of gratifying perſonal vanity or mere animal appetite. —Lord Lovemore is to ſunk in my eſteem, that I can place no confidence in his honour. I ſhall ſo far take the letter-writer's advice, therefore, as to watch his motions to night very narrowly. Enter Mrs. GOODWILL.
Oh! Mrs. Goodwill! if General Gantlet ſhould return I have a little plot upon him, which you muſt aſſiſt me in. Lady Lovemore wiſhes to be revenged on him for the fright he has juſt put her in. Now the General was duelling yeſterday and wounded his antagoniſt : the wounds I underſtand are not dangerous, but it will be eaſy for us to perſuade him that they are mortal.

sp.speaker: Mrs. GOOD.
sp.p: An excellent device, if it ſhould but terrify him to run away! His honour and dignity would be finely mortified before he diſcovered the trick that was put on him.

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: Egad, here he comes—do you be within hearing, Mrs. Goodwill, and ſecond my attempt as you ſee neceſſary.

sp.speaker: Mrs. GOOD.
sp.p: You may depend on me, Sir. [Exit.

div.stage: Re-enter General GANTLET.

sp.speaker: GAN.
sp.p: I forgot, Boothby, to aſk you if you intend playing the fool at the Hay-market, to night. —I think of going.

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: Egad, General, I believe you had better think of a prudent expedition to the continent. You acted the part of a man, it ſeems, ſo ſeriouſly with your antagoniſt yeſterday, that you ſhould be careful how you play the fool to night. I underſtand he lies at the point of death.

sp.speaker: GAN.
sp.p: Zounds! The ſurgeon told me he was in no danger.

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: Yes, but it ſeems they have called in another of more dangerous practice, and he declares otherwiſe. So that if the man dies, General, the lawyers, who know nothing about the point of honour, you know—

sp.speaker: GAN.
sp.p: Confound the ſurgeons and the lawyers too—Die! let him die and be ſepulchred on a dunghill.

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: Nay, but confider, General, I would have you make off by all means, and get out of the kingdom as faſt as you can.

sp.speaker: GAN.
sp.p: Make off! What like a houſe-breaker or a highwayman! Make off!

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: Nay, General, don't be angry. —But if you ſtay, and matters ſtand as I hear them related, you will run the utmoſt danger.

sp.speaker: GAN.
sp.p: But is it not derogatory to a man's dignity to fly from danger?

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: If it threatened only from the point of a bayonet or the mouth of a culverin, I grant you, General. But when it appears in the form of a halter and the gallows.

sp.speaker: GAN.
sp.p: Egad, you ſay true, Boothby, there is no dignity in the gallows. I will decamp.

div.stage: Enter Mrs. GOODWILL in haſte.

sp.speaker: Mrs. GOOD.
sp.p: Bleſs me, gentlemen, I am almoſt frightened out of my wits. —Here has been two of Sir John Fielding's people enquiring after General Gantlet : But as I heard of the ugly affair that happened yeſterday, I ſaid his honour was not here—The ſervant ſays they are ſtill lurking about the ſtreet. Therefore pray take care how you go out, General. —What a thing it would be if your honour's dignity ſhould come to be hanged.

sp.speaker: G. GAN.
sp.p: Hell and the devil! what ſhall I do—Not that I value my life, Capt. Boothby, of a button. I have ſhewn that at the head of a line of battle : but to be throttled with a halter! the indignity of it, Boothby! I ſhall die with ſhame under the indignity of it.

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: Let me ſee—What can be done in this emergency? You might eſcape under diſguiſe ; and that the more readily as it is maſquerade night. —But a domino is not ſufficient, and I have no other at hand.

sp.speaker: Mrs. GOOD.
sp.p: What think you of women's apparel, Sir? I can furniſh his honour with a ſack and petticoat.

sp.speaker: GAN.
sp.p: A petticoat!

sp.speaker: Mrs. GOOD.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, I'll run and fetch it immediately. [Exit.

sp.speaker: GAN.
sp.p: A petticoat! I will be taken, hanged, drawn and quartered, e're I put on a petticoat. A ſoldier, a commander, wear a petticoat!

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p:
Pſhaw! General, there is nothing in a petticoat, which the braveſt man upon earth need he offended at. Achilles, you know, who out-hectored Hector, was glad to conceal himſelf under one of his mother's maids ſhort petticoats,
Nay, Hercules himſelf changed his club for a diſtaff, and threw off his lion's ſkin, to put on fair Omphale's petticoat.

sp.speaker: GAN.
sp.p: By the Lord, you ſay true : egad, I had forgot it. A man, as you ſay, may be as valiant as Hercules, and yet be glad ſometimes to creep under a petticoat. Where, where is it?

div.stage: Enter Mrs. GOODWILL with a tête, ſack, and petticoat.

sp.speaker: Mrs. GOOD.
sp.p: Here, here, Sir, with a lady's tête too, to complete the diſguiſe.

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: Ay, this is the very thing, Mrs. Goodwill. [Booth. and Mrs. Good. aſſiſt to dreſs Gant.

sp.speaker: GAN.
sp.p: [while, he is dreſſing] Lookye, Boothby, it is not becauſe I fear to die. —I have ſhewn that, as I ſaid before, in the field of battle. —Nor that I think I have done wrong in ridding the world of a raſcal—I could die with a ſafe conſcience! —But the manner of it, Boothby! —The manner of it! I would avoid the indignity of being carted with ſtreet-robbers and footpads, Might I be indulged in the ſatisfaction of being blown from the mouth of a cannon, or plead privilege to have the honour of being decapitated like a gentleman, may I be crucified if I would budge a foot. — But to be dragged like a calf, with a rope about its neck to the ſlaughter ; to hear wide-mouthed hawkers cry my laſt dyingſpeech and confeſſion! —Come, come, Mrs. Goodwill, make haſte with your petticoat. —Hercules himſelf wore a petticoat.

sp.speaker: Mrs. GOOD.
sp.p: There, Sir, 'twill do very well—Now for your tête.

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: An admirable diſguiſe—and well fitted.

sp.speaker: Mrs. GOOD.
sp.p: And very becoming too, I proteſt—Oh! and here, your honour, is your Ladyſhip's fan. [taking a fan out of her pocket.]

sp.speaker: GAN.
sp.p: Ay, ay, come give me my truncheon. [taking the fan.]

sp.speaker: Mrs. GOOD,
sp.p: [aſide] Well, if this does not cure him of duelling, he ſhould have a ſtatute of lunacy taken out againſt him and be ſhut up in the hoſpital of incurables. [Exit.

sp.speaker: GAN.
sp.p: (after looking at himſelf for ſome time.) So! a pretty figure for a General! Eh, Boothby! I would not have you think, my dear boy, that it is out of fear I ſubmit to wear this effeminate diſguiſe ; it is only to avoid ſuffering an indignity unbecoming a man. Ever while you live, Boothby, preſerve the dignity of man!

div.stage: [Exeunt GAN. fanning himſelf and holding up his train.

div.head: SCENE I. Capt. Boothby's Lodgings.
div.stage: Enter BOOTHBY and WITMORE.

sp.speaker: BOOTH,
sp.p: How! talk of ſhipping the young lady back to India! He dare not attempt it, ſure!

sp.speaker: WIT.
sp.p: It is hard to ſay what an India Governor, accuſtomed to the inſolence of Aſiatic tyranny, may not attempt. His wealth may promiſe him impunity ; and a ſtep of that kind is eaſier prevented than amended. I have prevailed on Emilia, therefore, to give her aunt the ſlip and take refuge with Mrs. Boothby, to night. Tomorrow we ſhall ſeek another aſylum.

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p:
I rejoice at the occaſion afforded me of obliging my friend, as I dare ſay Mrs. Boothby will, at that of aſſiſting my couſin. —Mrs. Goodwill. Enter Mrs. GOODWILL.
Pleaſe to let Mrs. Boothby know I would ſpeak to her.

sp.speaker: Mrs. GOOD.
sp.p: She bade me tell you, Sir, ſhe was gone to the maſquerade. She ſaid you knew her dreſs, which might be eaſily diſtinguiſhed among the maſks.

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: This is unlucky. But no matter, you'll bring the lady here, Witmore, Mrs. Goodwill may be truſted, and will attend you till Mrs. Boothby returns.

sp.speaker: WIT.
sp.p: I ſhall be obliged to her—You may expect us preſently, Mrs. Goodwill. (Exit.

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: So, Lady Lovemore has taken Mrs. Boothby to the maſquerade, you ſay, Mrs. Goodwill.

sp.speaker: Mrs. GOOD.
sp.p: Oh no, Sir. Lady Lovemore ſent to excuſe herſelf : his Lordſhip alſo called afterwards, to acquaint Mrs. Boothby that an accident had happened, which prevented her ladyſhip from ſtirring out to night.

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: And did my wife go with his Lordſhip?

sp.speaker: Mrs. GOOD.
sp.p: No, Sir, but, as he was very preſſing for her to do it, ſhe promiſed to follow him,

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p:
How! it was highly indiſcreet of her. Mrs. Goodwill to go alone. Be ſo obliging as to fetch my domino and maſk down ſtairs. madam—I muſt follow her immediately. (Exit Mrs. Goodwill. BOOTHBY alone.
I dont half like Lady Lovemore's ſtaying at home and his Lordſhip's officiouſneſs, in ſeconding her meſſages and preſſing my wife to accompany him. —And yet there can be no deſign in it, ſure! —My wife refuſed to go with him. —Yes, but it ſeem ſhe promiſed to follow him ; and he knows, to her knowledge too, the habit ſhe was to appear in. —That —That —Zounds! what a tedious while this woman ſtays! I might almoſt have been with them by this time. (Exit

div.head: SCENE II. Sir Solomon Bauble's.
div.stage: Enter Lady BAUBLE and Mrs. BRUSH.

sp.speaker: Lady BAU.
sp.p: Gone out at this time of night! Emilia! my niece! Gone out! do you ſay?

BRUSH. Yes, my lady. She ſaid, becauſe his worſhip had loſt his beſt Othur yeſterday, ſhe would ſee that the ſtreetdoor was locked to night herſelf. The Antic-queerians, ſhe ſaid, might run away with her, for ought ſhe knew. I thoft ſhe was coming up ſtairs immediately ; I thoft no harm.

sp.speaker: Lady BAU.
sp.p: And you let her go by herſelf, you illiterate, careleſs creature! did you? Some ruffians may have ruſhed in and carried her off by violence.

sp.speaker: BRUSH.
sp.p: Very likely, my Lady, for I thoft I ſaw an ill-looking fellow, like a ſervant out of place, in an old livery, hankering and hankering about the door all the evening.

sp.speaker: Lady BAU.
sp.p: And why did not you tell me of it, then, you ſlut? My niece might be raviſhed, murdered, married, for ought you cared! Here, where is Sir Solomon? —Run all of you, ſome one way and ſome another. Alarm the watch, call up the conſtable —go dirctly for Governor Mammon — Where, where is Sir Solomon! — [Exeunt Bruſh, and Servants.

div.stage: Enter Sir SOLOMON BAUBLE.

sp.speaker: Sir SOL.
sp.p: Here, here, who calls! I was only juſt taking leave of my princeſs before I went to bed, my lady.

sp.speaker: Lady BAU.
sp.p: Out updn your Princeſs—I wiſh you was bedded to her with all my heart. —You are a pretty guardian truly to take more care of a mummy than of your ward.

sp.speaker: Sir SOL.
sp.p: My ward! why what's the matter, wiſe?

sp.speaker: Lady BAU.
sp.p: Matter enough Sir, ſomebody has carried off your niece.

sp.speaker: Sir SOL.
sp.p: How! carried off Emilia! Run away with her by force?

sp.speaker: Lady BAU.
sp.p: Nay, I know not that : ſhe may have followed the example of your daughter for ought I know. The collateral branches of the family may poſſibly take after one another, tho' they diverge in the deſcending line. —I wonder your maſculine ſagacity, Sir Solomon, did not foreſee this diſaſter.

sp.speaker: Sir SOL.
sp.p: I don't wonder that your feminine foreſight did not prevent it! Woman's wit! quotha! —But who went with her! —Which way went ſhe? —

sp.speaker: Lady BAU.
sp.p: Nay, if we knew that, we might know which way to go after her.

div.stage: Enter Mrs. BRUSH and a WATCHMAN.

sp.speaker: Sir SOL.
sp.p: Well. Watchman, did you ſee any thing of a young Lady, who looked as if the was running away with herſelf?

sp.speaker: WAT.
sp.p: Your worſhip's kinſwoman, Sir, Madam Emily, I think they call her, paſſed by my ſtand juſt now.

sp.speaker: Lady BAU.
sp.p: Any body with her?

sp.speaker: WAT.
sp.p: A young gentleman, as my partner ſays, belonging to the Temple : He knows them, for my part I does not know neither him nor ſhe.

sp.speaker: Sir SOL.
sp.p: A templar! eh! a ſad dog, I'll warrant him, my lady.

sp.speaker: Lady BAU.
sp.p: Oh, a pretty rake! no doubt.

sp.speaker: WAT.
sp.p: For my part, I took her for a crack ; as the gentleman called a coach off the ſtand and bid him drive toward Covent Garden.

sp.speaker: Lady BAU.
sp.p: Run, fly, Mr. Watchman, purſue the coach. Go, fellow, run. [Exit. Enter

div.stage: Enter THOMAS.

sp.speaker: Sir SOL.
sp.p: Well, Sir, where have you been?

sp.speaker: THO.
sp.p: After my young miſtreſs, Sir, —And I came back to tell you that the coach drove ſo conſounded faſt that I could not overtake it.

sp.speaker: Sir SOL.
sp.p: Why did you not run faſter then, blockhead?

sp.speaker: THO.
sp.p: I did Sir. And yet, for all that, had it not ſtopped when it did, I ſhould have never have come up with it.

sp.speaker: Lady BAU.
sp.p: Then it did ſtop, and you did come up with it. Eh!

sp.speaker: THO.
sp.p: Yes, my lady, at the door of a habit ſhop in Taviſtock Street. I ſuppoſe the gentleman and miſs are going to the maſquerade. So I thought that, while they were putting on their dreſſes, I would juſt ſtep back, to let your Ladyſhip and his Worſhip know where to find them.

sp.speaker: Sir SOL.
sp.p: Well done Thomas. Yes, yes I'll be with them preſently. Give me my roccelo and bid ſomebody run and call a coach.

sp.speaker: Lady BAU.
sp.p: And me a chair. I'll ſlip on my things and go with you. Come Bruſh get me any bonnet and cloak. [Exit.

div.stage: THOMAS re-enters with Sir SOLOMON's Roccelo, Hat ana Cane.

sp.p: Sir SOL. And do you hear, Thomas—run you to Governor Mammon and bring him after us immediately. —I'll deliver my niece into his hands this very night, I proteſt. You have done well Thomas—Bring Governor Mammon with you immediately. And, do you hear, Thomas for fear we ſhould want aſſiſtance, tell his Banyan to muſter up his attendants; from his Dallals and Darògas, down to his honour's Pykes, Peons and Cooleys. Do you hear Thomas!

sp.speaker: THO.
sp.p: I will Sir. Exeunt.

div.head: SCENE III. Boothby's Lodgings.
div.stage: Enter WITMORE, and EMILIA followed by Mr. GOODWILL.

sp.speaker: WIT.
sp.p: Don't be flurried, my dear Emilia, we are arrived ſafe.

sp.speaker: EM.
sp.p: I am ſo frightened, leſt they ſhould have followed and watched us in.

sp.speaker: WIT.
sp.p: Don't be apprehenſive, my dear girl. —As we left the coach at the door of the habit-ſhop, and you came away maſked in a chair, we have certainly eluded the vigilance of our purſuers, if there were any.

sp.speaker: Mrs. GOOD.
sp.p:
This way Madam if you pleaſe. This way, Sir, be under no apprehenſions of ſurprize : The ſervants will let no ſtranger in without giving me notice. Exeunt. Enter BOOTHBY.
Curſe on my fooliſh curioſity! How miſerable it has made me! I did not think I could have been ſo ſuddenly jealous. My wife Cannot ſure encourage Lord Lnvemore! And yet, as I watched them about the rooms, I ſurprized her in ſuch familiar converſation with him. She did not ſpeak loud enough for me to hear what ſhe ſaid, indeed ; but ſhe ſeemed to whiſper ſo frequently ; and her ſigns were ſo ſignificantly encouraging, her attitudes ſo provokingly inviting, that I was ſeveral times in the mind to pluck the maſk from her face and expoſe her, him and myſelf, to the Company.—I did not imagine ſhe could ſo readily have entered into the ſpirit of the place. — —Who knows, in her gaité de coeur, how far things may be carried!
They may have left the rooms for greater freedom of converſation elſewhere. —Confound the crowd in which I loſt fight of them. [Going ; Stops ſhort. Ha! here they are! —Bring him home to her own lodgings! Is this ſimplicity or art! —I fear I have been made their dupe. —But I'll ſee a little more. [Retires behind the Scene.

div.stage: Enter Lord LOVEMORE in a domino, with a maſk in his hand, leading a Lady in a fancy dreſs, maſked.

sp.speaker: Lord LOVE.
sp.p: Nay, my dear Mrs. Boothby, why carry on the farce now?

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: [aſide] My dear Mrs. Boothby! Yes, yes, I am now convinced. —It is clear they have made a dupe of me.

sp.speaker: Lord LOVE.
sp.p: Not one word! Have you ſo kindly invited me home not to ſpeak to me? Will not your tongue confirm my happineſs? By this hand I will force the ſeal of ſilence •• om thoſe charming lips with kiſſes. [offers to kiſs the Lady.

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: By this band, my Lord, but you ſhall not. [Laying hold of Lard Lovemore's arm.

sp.speaker: LADY.
sp.p: Oh! [ſcreams and runs off.]

div.stage: [After ſometime looking at each other.]

sp.speaker: Lord LOVE.
sp.p: Capt. Boothby!

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p:
Lord Loveinore! —Your Lordſhip has ſome grace left I ſee by your confuſion. And ſo my dear Mrs. Boothby has kindly invited you home, and after all won't ſpeak to yeu. —I will lay my commands on her, my Lord, ſhe ſhall ſpeak to you. —Come forth, Mrs. Boothby ; come forth and ſpeak to Lord Lovemore ; his Lordſhip is impatient to hear the confirmation of his happineſs from thoſe charming lips. [Going up to door finds it locked. Ha! locked! —Open the door this inſtant, madam, or, by
heavens I'll ſplit it into a thouſand pieces, Provoke not the rage of an injured huſband, left he ſhould be no longer able to reſtrain it.

sp.speaker: Lord LOVE.
sp.p: On my honour, Mr. Boothby, no injury hath been done you.

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: Perhaps leſs than was intended, my Lord : but I am convinced it was not your fault that an irreparable injury is not done me. I am not ſo credulous, therefore, as to take your Lordſhip's word. Your honour, my Lord, is a bad ſecurity for your veracity. We muſt hear what Mrs. Boothby ſays to it. Come forth, I ſay, Madam — Mrs. Boothby!

div.stage: Enter Mrs. BOOTHBY with, Mrs. GOODWILL, from another part of the ſcene.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BOOTH.
sp.p: Who calls me ſo loudly? —Mr. Boothby! [Lord Lovemore and Capt. Boothby look with ſurprize at each other.

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: So ſoon undreſſed, madam! This is maſquerading indeed! Did not you go into this room juſt now, in the habit, I ſaw you dreſſed in to night at the Haymarket?

sp.speaker: Mrs. BOOTH.
sp.p: You forgot, my dear, that there is no other door to that room. Nor did you ſee me to night dreſſed in any habit at the Haymarket.

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: How! madam! Would you perſuade me I did not know you? Did not you, Mrs. Goodwill, ſay my wife was gone to the maſquerade?

sp.speaker: Mrs. GOOD.
sp.p: I ſaid, Sir, your Lady bade me tell you ſo.

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: No prevaricating, no ſhuffling madam! I ſay, my wife was to night at the maſquerde.

sp.speaker: Mrs. GOOD.
sp.p:
And I can anſwer for Ms. Boothby, Sir, that ſhe has not been out of doors to night. —She has been
converſing for ſome time with the gentleman and lady, you ecpected ; who are now above ſtairs.

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: Mr. Witmore and Emilia!

sp.speaker: Ms. BOOTH.
sp.p: It is even ſo, my dear. Being diſappointed of my habit, I ſent to acquaint Lady Lovemore of it. who returned me word that an unforeſeen accident likewiſe prevented her Ladyſhip's going. Indeed my Lord came afterwards to apologize for her, and preſſed me ſo hard to accompany him, that, in order to get rid of his importunity, I was in a manner obliged to promiſe I would follow him : ſo that Mrs. Goodwill told you no untruth.

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: But why impoſe on me by equivocation?

sp.speaker: Mrs. BOOTH.
sp.p: That I mightoot deprive yoo of an amuſement, my dear, merely becauſe I could not partake of it myſelf, I thought you would return when you did not find me among the maſks.

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: I thought I had found you, madam.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BOOTH.
sp.p: In the perſon, I ſuppoſe, to whom my habit was ſent by miſtake. You have no reaſon, I hope, to be much diſpleaſed at your diſappointment.

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: As you were prudent enough to diſappoint his Lordſhip, I am ſatisfied.

sp.speaker: Lord LOVE.
sp.p: That is more than I am. —As Lady Love-more is at home, and Mrs. Boothby has not been abroad all the evening, you will give me leave to ſee who is in this room.

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: Force open the door, then, my Lord, you conducted hither the Lady who went into it.

sp.speaker: Lord LOVE.
sp.p: That I will, without ceremony. [Ruſhes agaiſt the door, forces it open and goes in.

sp.speaker: Mrs. GOOD.
sp.p: (aſide) What violence is this?

sp.speaker: Mrs. BOOTH.
sp.p: What is all this, Mr. Boothby?

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p:
We ſhall ſee preſently, my dear. As yet I hardly know myſelf. Some demirp, I ſupooſe, has been
quetting with Lord Lovemore : but his reaſon for bringing her hither is ſomewhat particular.

div.stage: Re-enter Lord LOVEMORE leading in the Lady, ſtill maſked.

sp.speaker: Lord LOVE.
sp.p: Come, madam, will you be pleaſed to unmaſk, that I may know to whom I am obliged for ſo many civilities? [The Lady unmaſks. ALL but Lord Lovemore. Lady Lovemore! Ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Lord LOVE.
sp.p: 'Sdeath! —have I been all this while making love to my own wife? —What a contemptible figure do I make here!

sp.speaker: Lady LOVE.
sp.p: Come, come, my Lord, don't babaſhed. If you can be but half ſo gallant at home as I find you can be abroad, you may yet have no reaſon to repent it.

sp.speaker: Lord LOVE.
sp.p: You, madam, may have reaſon though to repent of this fine foolery.

sp.speaker: Lady LOVE.
sp.p: I ſhall never repent, my Lord, of preventing you doing what you yourſelf would have-much more reaſon to repent of. —Mrs. Boothby, I hope, will excuſe my perſonating her on this occaſion, as well as the artifices I made uſe of, to procure her habit and detain her at home.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BOOTH.
sp.p: Your Ladyſhip need not apologize to me for any thing that is paſt.

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: And what ſays Lord Lovemore to what has paſt?

sp.speaker: Lord LOVE.
sp.p: Nothing, Sir. I am neither diſpoſed to aſk pardon nor bear reproof. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Lady LOVE.
sp.p: Well ſaid, Lord Lovemore! Carry it off like yourſelf. But I muſt have ſome talk with you on this buſineſs; and that immediately too. [Exit.

div.stage: Enter Sir SOLOMON and LADY BAUBLE.

sp.speaker: Sir SOL.
sp.p: Ay, ay, this is the houſe, this is the houſe, my Lady. —Let the conſtables wait without.

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: What's this? Sir Solomon! my father in law!

sp.speaker: Sir SOL.
sp.p: I diſclaim you, Sir. —Where is my niece Emmiline? What! would not the robbing me of a daughter content you, but you muſt likewiſe ſeduce my ward?

sp.speaker: Lady BAU.
sp.p: And you, my pretty ſormal, ſugitive daughter, was it not enough that you had ruined yourſelf, but you muſt aſſiſt in the ruin of your run-away couſin too? —Where is ſhe?

sp.speaker: Sir SOL.
sp.p: Ay, where is ſhe! Let her appear this moment, or we'll call in the conſtables and break open the doors. She was ſeen to come in here.

sp.speaker: Lady BAU.
sp.p: Ay, ay, call in the conſtables, Sir Solomon ; and let them break open the doors.

div.stage: A noiſe is heard without. Enter a CONSTABLE.

sp.speaker: CONST.
sp.p: [coming in] Stand aſide, ſtand aſide there ; the young lady is found ; let her come in.

sp.speaker: Sir SOL.
sp.p: How! I thought they ſaid ſhe was already in the houſe.

sp.speaker: CONST.
sp.p: No! no! Sir! We ſtopped her, an' pleaſe your worſhip, as ſhe was coming out of a chair to get into a poſtchaiſe, to ſet off for France. Had not ſhe ſeemed ſhy of being ſeen, we ſhould not have ſuſpected her. She's very obſtropulous for a young lady! ſhe won't let us ſee her face—ſo that we are ſure it muſt be ſhe. —Let the lady come in, there.

div.stage: Enter GENERAL GANTLET ſtill in woman's cloaths.

sp.speaker: CONST.
sp.p: Come miſs—you'll let theſe gentleſolks ſee your face, I ſuppoſe.

sp.speaker: GAN.
sp.p: [aſide] Zounds! What a congregation are got together here!

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: [aſide] The General! What a whimſical incident! I muſt ſave his dignity farther mortification, or we ſhall have him quite outrageous.

sp.speaker: Sir SOL.
sp.p: Emily! that—that—Emily!

sp.speaker: Lady BAU.
sp.p: What a metamorphoſis! I proteſt, ſhe is ſo transformed, Sir Solomon, that I ſhould not have known her. Come, madam, pray unmaſk, and let us ſee the natural features of that bold face of thine [going up to the General, to pull off his maſk].

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: Hold, madam! my apartments are the young lady's protection. I receive company on all theſe public nights and nobody mult be unmaſked here againſt their will. [Turning to the General] This way, madam, if you pleaſe : Mrs. Goodwill, be ſo good as to ſhew the lady up to the drawing room [Boothby leads General Gantlet acroſs the ſiage, and beckons to Mrs. Goodwill who goes off with him].

sp.speaker: Lady BAU.
sp.p: Don't tell me [running up and ſuatching off Gantlet's maſk, as Mrs. Goodwill leads him off]. Oh!

sp.speaker: Sir SOL.
sp.p: What's the matter, my Lady? What, ſrightened at your niec!

sp.speaker: Lady BAU.
sp.p: No, no, that hard-featured thing is more likely to be her gallant.

sp.speaker: Sir SOL.
sp.p: Her gallant! What in petticoats! Fine doings theſe!

sp.speaker: Lady BAU.
sp.p: Yes, yes, your niece is got into fine company here—but if I don't rout them—Here, where's the conſtable.

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: Hold, madam. Your Ladyſhip muſt excuſe me, if I prevent you from expoſing yourſelf here.

sp.speaker: Sir SOL.
sp.p: How Sir! will you detain a ward from her guardian?

sp.speaker: Lady BAU.
sp.p: Oh! here comes the Governor. We ſhall hear what he ſays to it.

div.stage: Enter Governor MAMMON followed by THOMAS.

sp.speaker: G. MAM.
sp.p: Wait without there.

Sir SOL. 'Tis well you are come, Governor—Egad, you had like to have been a wife out of pocket, I can tell you. — Mr. Conſtable look well to the doors—Thomas, ſee that nobody ſhips out. [Exeunt THOMAS and CONSTABLE.

sp.speaker: G. MAM.
sp.p: Is the young lady overtaken then, Sir Solomon?

sp.speaker: Sir. SOL.
sp.p: Yes, yes, we have houſed her. She's ſafe enough above ſtairs, if we can but prevail on this gentleman to part with her. Though he cares not for the authority of fathers or guardians, he may reſpect perhaps the prerogatives and privileges of a huſband!

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: A huſband, Sir Solomon I Is your niece then the gentleman's wife?

sp.speaker: G. MAM.
sp.p: She muſt be, Sir, if I'm diſpoſed to marry her.

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: Perhaps not, Sir, if ſhe is not ſo already : but here ſhe comes.

div.stage: Enter Mr. WITMORE and EMILIA.

sp.speaker: Lady BAU.
sp.p: Another metamorphoſis! So, madam, you thought your ſhallow cunning could outwit your uncle's and my profound ſagacity, did you?

sp.speaker: G. MAM.
sp.p: [to Wit.] How, Mr. Witmore! Is it you that are my rival?

sp.speaker: WIT.
sp.p: The young lady, Governor, hath preferred me to be her guardian ; and no violence muſt be offered her inclinations.

sp.speaker: G. MAM.
sp.p: Nor ſhall there, Barriſter, on my account, I promiſe you.

sp.speaker: Sir SOL.
sp.p: How, Sir!

sp.speaker: G. MAM.
sp.p: I have this afternoon, Sir Solomon, been informed by a relation, whom I adviſed of my arrival, that this young Barriſter is my nephew.

sp.speaker: WIT.
sp.p: Sir!

sp.speaker: Sir SOL.
sp.p: How! the Governor your uncle! and you ſo undutiful at not to know any thing about him!

sp.speaker: G. MAM.
sp.p: His ignorance of me is excuſeable, Sir Solomon : It is long ſince I correſponded with the family. —He may poſſibly have heard of me, but there have been ſo many Mammons of late years imported from India, that, had the name implied affinity, he might have expected a cargo of couſins by every fleet. But know me now, young gentleman, for your uncle [embracing him.]

sp.speaker: Lady BAU.
sp.p: Well, but what is to become of our niece!

sp.speaker: G. MAM.
sp.p: Why, give her to my kinſman, Madam. I really think the young lady hath provided better for herſelf than her friends had provided for her.

sp.speaker: Sir SOL.
sp.p: And do you reſign her to him, Governor?

sp.speaker: G. MAM,
sp.p: Why, look ye, Sir Solomon, I did not chuſe to forfeit my lack of Rupees; but as the money will not now go out of the family, I can refign the lady without reluctance. So that, if you conſent to their marriage, the young folks ſhall not be diſappointed.

sp.speaker: Sir SOL.
sp.p: Well, what ſay you to the propoſal, my lady?

sp.speaker: Lady BAU.
sp.p: Say! Sir Solomon! What is there to be ſaid? Governor Mammon having a right to claim Emilia for himſelf, he has a fortiori, as the Logicians ſay, a right to diſpoſe of her to his Nephew.

sp.speaker: Sir SOL.
sp.p: Well then, Barriſter, with the Governor's leave, I don't ſay take her ; but, as you have got, you may keep her.

sp.speaker: WIT.
sp.p: I thank you, Sir Solomon. —But to you, Sir, [Speaking to Governor Mammon.] I know not how to make my acknowledgements.

sp.speaker: G. MAM.
sp.p: When we are better acquainted, Nephew, you may learn.

sp.speaker: Sir SOL.
sp.p: Ay, ay—and, as you have got ſo good an Uncle and a wife into the bargain, Barriſter, you ought to be ſatisfied.

sp.speaker: WIT.
sp.p: Not quite, Sir. You will give me leave to hope you will extend your goodneſs alſo to my friend Boothby and your daughter.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BOOTH.
sp.p: May I hope for ſo great a bleſſing as your pardon, madam? [To Lady Bauble.]

sp.speaker: Lady BAU.
sp.p: Sir Solomon!

sp.speaker: Sir SOL.
sp.p: Nay, if it reſts with me—there—there, take both our bleſſings between you. It is all I can ſpru at preſent, tho'; take that with you.

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: I hope otherwiſe, Sir.

sp.speaker: WIT.
sp.p: Never fear, Boothby ; when favour once comes, fortune will ſoon follow.

div.stage: Enter General GANTLET in his own cloathes.

sp.speaker: G. GAN.
sp.p: By heavens, this is not to be put up with. Bedizen'd like a ſtrumpet, dogg'd by thief-takers, dragged along like a ſtreet-walker! —Capt. Boothby, I muſt have ſatisfaction for all this ; I underſtand it was a plot of yours and my lady ſiſter's, to expoſe me. As to her, ſhe is a woman, and I'll have nothing more to do with petticoats.

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: Faith, General, I aſk your pardon with all my heart. But I acted in concert with Lady Lovemore merely to ſet this ſavage cuſtom of duelling, you are ſo abſurdly fond of, in a ridiculous light.

sp.speaker: G. GAN.
sp.p: Yes, faith, I feel myſelf ridiculous enough in all conſcience. But my dignity, Boothby!

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p:
How, General! Doth dignity conſiſt in the brutal cuſtom of cutting throats, like cannibals, in cold
blood ? Did the heroes of antiquity want dignity? Yet did Caeſar ever ſend a challenge to Cato, or Cato to Caeſar?

sp.speaker: G. GAN.
sp.p: Caeſar and Cato, Boothby, were clever fellows, in their day, no doubt. Yes, your Caeſars and Catos muſt have been fine fellows in there time. But ſword and piſtol were not then in vogue, and the fighting one's friends was not come in faſhion. You may call me abſurd, if you will ; but how is a man of honour at preſent to ſupport his conſequence without having recourſe to the Duel ?

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: By having recourſe to his good-nature, my dear General : Believe me, there is often more fortitude in forgiving an injury than in revenging it ; and always more dignity in deſpiſing inſults than in reſenting them.

div.head: EPILOGUE.
div.p: And ſpoken by Miſs BARSANTI.

sp.l: WELL, men of valour! how do ye like our play?
Nothing againſt it, ſure, the Ladies ſay! —
To own they're pleas'd the critics ever loth,
May cry "A Duelliſt with ſcarce an oath!
"'Tis like his hat, that was without a feather. —
"Duels and dammes, always go together."
Old ſinners, loving the licentious joke,
May think there wants too here and there a ſtroke ;
Round oaths and double meanings, ſtrew'd between,
With them the virtues of the comic ſcene.
And yet the Town in general is ſo nice,
It holds theſe virtues as a kind of vice.
From the teeth outwards chaſte, their hands before 'em,
Like reps, ev'n demireps are all decorum.
Though groſs their thoughts, ſo delicate their hearing,
They think the very ſtage ſhould fine for ſwearing.
Our author, therefore, ſcrupled to employ
Your vulgar damme Sir, and damme boy;
Nay, when by chance a naughty joke came pat in,
He wrapt it up, you know, in lawyer's Latin Alluding to a paſſage in the play, which the Author, in deference to the delicacy of certain Ladies, who underſtand Latin, has omitted..
So much refin'd the ſcene ſince former days,
When Congreve, Vanbrugh, Wycherly wrote plays,
"The ſtage ſo looſely did Aſtrea tread,
"She fairly put all characters to bed ;
Tho' now no bard would venture to depoſit
A Macaroni in a lady's cloſet ;
Leſt the ſrail fair one he be thought to ruin,
While moon and ſtars alone—ſee what they're doing.
In the old plays, gallants take no denial,
But put the ſtruggling actreſs to the trial.
B1eſs me! I ſhudder ev'n now to think
How near ev'n I may ſtand on dangers brink.
In modern plays, more ſafe the female ſtation ;
Secure as ſad our ſolemn ſituation!
No rakiſh, forward ſpark dares now be rude :
The Comic Muſe herſelf grown quite a prude!
No wonder then, if, in ſo pure an age,
No Congreves write for as demure a ſtage.
